I had the Eggs Blackstone. Eggs were poached perfectly and the hollandaise seemed to be homemade, not from a mix or delivered via Sysco or something. I mean I got more and dipped my home fries in it. YUM.



Unique restau, will absolutely get back. Next time I will try the biscuits and gravy. Looked good too!
author: Yma Y.

description: Great off the beaten path NON tourist trap brunch spot.  Neighborhood is definitely a bit run down, but this was a great find.  Beignets were great, scramble was fantastic, service was wonderful.  We loved it.  Nice to go somewhere in SF and find parking easily and feel like we were eating among locals, not among a bunch of tourists from Kansas City.
author: Will S.

description:
Such a bustling place for brunch. Even though it may be a long wait, you don't have to wait long for your food!! We first got the beignets, first reaction, OMG. They're HUGE!!! (Don't say it, I know what you're thinking) Anyways, it's this 4"x4" fluffy sweetness. So great to start your brunch with. I then got the greg's omelette with chorizo and home fries. Oh man, this was so delicious with chorizo, onions, spinach in fluffy egg heaven. Also, if you get the english muffin, you should definitely get the gravy to go with it. Hope you're full after all that!

Oh, it's also cool, you can get a cup inside and fill up your cup with hot coffee while waiting outside.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: Met a friend there, Had breakfast. Ya, it gets busy on Saturdays, but thats a good thing. If it wasn't good, it wouldn't be busy.I love the place. I've been there multiple times, and was a bit of an ass in a previous review. i had beignets, grits and a veggie omelet, with a house turkey sausage patty. I was happy..And was happy the previous 4-5+times. I will go there again, and again, and again...
author: Kevin H.

description: Best beignet I have had so far, great New Orleans style coffee, an out-of-this-world frittata, home made bread, open nearly all the time when other places are closed and personable, attentive service. Can't wait to go back!
author: Tim K.

description:
Just For You Cafe is tucked into a little neighborhood, and it is better for it. It always makes me happy when I am able to dine at a local spot that does not have much pretension to offer. but that does offers all of the nit and grit of a unique breakfast-centric eatery.

This fusion sort of establishment offers a little Tex-Mex, a little Nawlins' flare, and a whole lot of craftiness in the kitchen. It gets packed in, so get ready to wait or take your order ta' go.

My buddy really wanted an egg sandwich, so luckily, I found him one. Friend with no egg sandwich make friend angry. Anyway, we ordered up one of those fried egg and bread combinations and a lonesome beignet.

The beignet was outstanding, a little heartier than one hailing from the wondrous New Orleans. It provided a touch of denseness, being more flat than usual, and the doughy center was just spot on. The Big Easy fried dough seems to be a little crispier and a little airier.

The egg sandwich was good, and I very much enjoyed the cinnamon raisin toast. Hands down, the best part was the sweet, supple tomato. You cannot make a good "fresh" sandwich without a great tomato slice. The egg was good, though a touch too cooked for my taste.

All in all, a fine breakfast joint, but the service was a bit off. Our dude did not say "you are welcome" or even a "greeting" in and out. That really took away from the appeal--who doesn't like a friendly server when they patronize a simple grub institution for their most important meal of the day?
author: Solomon W.

description:
Excellent in every way. 

- Good coffee while we wait. (there are always cute dogs outside too)
- Delicious huevos rancheros with green chili and chorizos. Give their chorizos a spin -- they are really good. 
- To die for beignets. So so good. 
- Friendly service. 
- Great prices. $4 for three large beignets.

Would take the caltrain up just to get brunch here!
author: Min L.

description: I really enjoy coming here, breakfast all day - you can't beat that! Sometimes there is a wait and you have to sign up on their wait list; however, now that they have this cute new Parklet (a parking space that has been turned into a mini 'park') that is open to the public I don't mind waiting. Eat here, service is always friendly and food is Yummy!
author: tOnii e.

description: Inside Just For You, you'll find a warm, inviting and bustling cafe with great food and personal service.  The grilled catfish (where else in SF can you get this for breakfast with eggs and grits) is better than the catfish I order at other well-known restaurants that are more known for it.  Everything on the menu is quite good, and I always leave feeling happy and well-fed.
author: Jackie A.

description:
This place just gets better with age. It reminds me of the really great neighborhood breakfast places where I grew up in Atlanta. Just a great homestyle breakfast / brunch place with a few inventive twists on the menu.

Used to live near Dogpatch and went there all of the time. Now moved to a diff part of the city so going back was really great after a long hiatus. 

A cyprus mimosa (with grapefruit juice) to get me in the mood. Then, tried something new this time. Scrambled eggs over cornbread and smothered in chili (a little tabasco added at the table). Wow! Sooooooo good. Scrambles are delish, too. But, chili was a nice change.

Oh, if you are feeling really naughty, there's nothing wrong with a little beignet appetizer! I'm just sayin'. Get there early if you don't like lines.
author: Robert W.

description:
Ughhh....I love when things are just for me.  Customized dresses. Customized Make-up palettes. I mean I could go on...and on...and on.  

Just For You Cafe was seriously made just for me.  I don't mean to sound narcissistic but seriously! I think they went into my mind and made sure that they served everything that I love for breakfast! Beignets that are fluffy and covered in a blanket of powdered sugar.  Longaniza sausage?!  I am part-filipina and trust me this is as good as it gets.  They may not make it the way my dad makes it back home, but hey they at least have it on the menu.  This combo is my remedy to curing those crazy hang overs I suffer from on Sundays after going out with my friends on Saturday.  

I love the coffee they have for patrons waiting to be seated inside their cozy restaurant - to me that's great customer service from the start.  The staff here is uber friendly and are quick to get whatever you need once you are seated.  

Definitely make the trip out to the Dogpatch for this to amazing breakfast spot to find the meal combo that is just for you ;)
author: Cherlyn M.

description: I don't know why people are always lined up around the block- the food is mediocre at best.  The portions are adequate for simple breakfast, service is fine, but the quality (flavor and tastiness) is lacking.  People are nice, it's great they have a new outdoor sidewalk patio seating area, the dogpatch is awesome - just wish the food was actually worth all the hype.
author: S R.

description:
Oh Lord, how I love this place. I have been going there almost every weekend for a year and I still can't get enough. The specials keep me from getting tired of the usual things on the menu. 

But, although I love this place and have given it 5 stars I will be honest about the bad parts. I was a hotel and restaurant major so I do see where some of the negative reviews are coming from.

BAD
1. Wait staff could use a few more sessions of training, if they even got any
            a. Service can be slow
            b. They can be rude

2. Location can be good or bad depending on your circumstances. I live in Pacific Heights so it is pretty far to travel just for breakfast, however I have a car and can always find close parking right on third street so it makes it very convenient if I have errands to run that day where I need my car.

***I have never had any problems with my food so I cannot comment on why people have said they can be inconsistent

GOOD
1. Food is amazing
        a. It is unique or hard to find New Orleans food
        b. Beignets are mouth watering..steamy hot that melts in your mouth
        c. Crab cake is sinful, perfect amount of spices and herbs
        d. Homemade turkey sausage patty was my addiction for months 
        e. Biscuits are sooo good, homemade and steamy hot

2. It is not pretentious (I wear sweats most of the time I go there) Customers are very friendly too.

3. Coffee is quite different than the typical coffee that I've had. I know someone who knows the owner of the restaurant and they say that she gets the coffee from New Orleans.

4. There is a decent wait and a list that you have to put your name on, and yes I know waiting sucks but it is a good sign if there is a wait because that means the food is worth waiting for by locals plus they give you free coffee outside...unlike Mama's on Washington Square.

Basically, whenever my family comes out to visit me I always take them there and I will be going there until they either close or I move. And while I do think the service sucks at times, it does kind of go with the personality of the restaurant...not pretentious.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Went in for brunch for the first time Friday morning.  Really liked the space and vibe of the place.  Sat at the counter and watched many great looking plates come out of the kitchen. 

We had Salad Nicoise and a Vegetarian Breakfast Burrito.  The salad was huge and fresh, tuna perfectly cooked.  The burrito was packed with fresh veggies, black beans and cheese.  YUM!  

Got a loaf of their cinnamon raisin bread for weekend brunch at home.  Perfect.  The entire time I was sitting at the counter I saw lots of cornbread slices leaving for the dining room, shoulda got a slice to go...  But then again, there's always next time.
author: Kim A.

description: I came here with my friend on a rainy Saturday early afternoon. Because of the rain, we only waited about 15 minutes for our table. :) I had the Hangtown Fry which consisted of 3 eggs scrambled with bacon, oysters, and onions. It was served with home fries and cornbread. Super delicious. There were quite a few big oysters in the scramble. If I had to compare, I prefer the Hangtown Fry at Brenda's just a bit more. The home fries are basically fried potatoes. They were not too crispy on the outside, yet they were well seasoned. We ordered the Beignets to go just because we were way too full from our meal. The Beignets are light, fluffy New Orleans-style donuts, smothered in powdered sugar. They were only $5 for 3 of them. What a deal! Since we got them to-go, it looked deflated in the to-go box. Nonetheless, they were still quite delicious! The beignets taste a bit sweet, yet soft and airy on the inside. I actually prefer the beignets here than at Brenda's. Overall, service was good that day and we were easily able to find parking within the next block.
author: Philana C.

description:
Should have written this review long ago....
Basically, 
Just For You Cafe 
immediately brings to mind my two other favorite "Beffis spots" 
in The City...
Pork Store on Haight,
and
Howards Cafe.
Got it?
Good.
author: Barry A.

description: My husband and I have been here a couple of times and the food has never disappointed us.  Great flavors, well cooked and a cozy atmosphere.  The beignets take us back to new orleans and we always get a plate to share each time we go.  The wait is never too long on the weekends and there is outdoor seating for those of you with dogs.
author: R C.

description:
I have been here a bunch of times now, and I am loving it more and more.  This past weekend I was there and ordered their french toast on gluten-free bread with a side of bacon. Check out this gorgeous breakfast!  I'm hungry all over again.

http://gonegluten-free.com/2011/05/15/good-for-you-cafe/
author: Heather S.

description:
Quaint little lunch/brunch spot with good food, friendly servers, and ample street parking.

**The beignets are awesomely fluffy, except I got too excited on the first bite and inhaled hella powdered sugar oO
author: Calvin W.

description: Parking is super easy to find. Absolutely love the cornmeal pancakes. Very little wait if you go before 10 am.
author: R P.

description:
They just opened for Dinner and we had a great experience.  The menu is original and there are so many great choices!  Prices are very reasonable.  The staff is incredibly nice.  The portions were outstanding -- we took so much home that we enjoyed a second meal the next night!  We wish that we had room for dessert, will plan on this when we return soon.

Don't miss the flatbread with portabellos and figs!

I highly recommend this restaurant for its great food in a casual atmosphere.  Chef Robert Del Real will make this a huge success with his delicious cuisine!
author: Michael T.

description:
This place is small and the wait can be long. Breakfast was solid but nothing special. Parking is easy in this area. I'm only rounding up because the beignets deserve 5 stars on their own!!

It's really good!! One alone is pretty big, enough to share for two. For that size, I was afraid it was going to be overfried and hard. But o contrare! It was crispy on the outside and surprisingly super fluffy once you bite into it.

I am S-O-L-D on their beignets! Don't wear black...you'll get powdered sugar all over you!
author: Ly T.

description:
JFY never disappoints.  Sort of a cooler, hipper-without-trying version of Toast in Noe (but with delicious food).  Feels like a diner, but with some great Southwestern specialties (and the best green chile sauce I've had outside New Mexico - awesome green chile cheeseburger!), delicious fish tacos, and a few other unexpected offerings.  Don't miss the baked goods - pies and beignets to die for.  

Lunches get busy so arrive just around noon if you don't like to wait.  I can imagine weekend brunches are pretty crowded as well.   A must when in the Potrero/Dogpatch area.
author: Katy M.

description: Such a great brunch spot. I'm usually pretty lucky about not having to wait too long during busy hours in the morning/ early afternoon on the weekends. Just sign up on the list once you get there and enjoy some sun (since its pretty much always sunny in that part of the city). All their breakfasts are delicious, and the beignets are to die for!! Don't forget to save some room for them :)
author: Ganesha B.

description: Very cute hole-n-the-wall place. Down home, good food, great service.
author: Jocelyn J.

description:
I'm in SF for the new years weekend all the while hoping the girls don't run wild and insist that we try some smarmy tofu serving mom and pop joint east of mission. Since being convicted and sentenced to eating brunch (if anything, Anthony Bourdain notes that brunch is the toilet pit of meals, a mishmash of sewage from leftover dinner materials) I figured I'll make the best of it. 

"Just For You" embodies the worst of SF dreck. I understand that having a line out the door at 2PM for BRUNCH can engender a sense of misplaced entitlement. That, however, does not excuse the fact that prices listed on the outside menu are drastically lower than the actual prices. $10 for glorified eggs and bacon? Fine, you're boutique. You serve dishes gluten-free upon request. But don't litter your windows with signs that say "we reserve the right to pour coffee on your phone" or "we like your baby, but not your stroller." Or, list items like soy milk on your menu but bold the statement underneath "we might have it sometimes, but don't count on it." 

It gets worse. The food came out late and and polenta sausage special would be pretty good if it wasn't lukewarm. I was mid bite through my meal when the wait staff came to try and clean our plates resulting in a literal tug of war between customer and waiter over half eaten breakfast sausage. No apology but still, no biggie. I dug around the other reviews beforehand and found comments about the excellent service. Maybe our server had a bad day but for the entire waiting staff and management embody this lassez-faire, f-you attitude is unacceptable. We attempted to split $85 on 4 credit cards, which is reasonable; yet, we were rudely asked for IDs. Are we in line at Vegas?

The incident that launched a thousand ships is when the receipts came back and I was charged $3.90 when I requested a $19 charge. I informed the waiter in hopes of making sure they got the tip they deserved. She came back telling me they actually charged $19 on the card but the receipt didn't reflect that. I remarked that it was disingenuous and proceeded to sign the receipt. She then bitches at me demanding why it was disingenuous when she already explained to me what happened. I understand that, lady, but my receipt is also a legal document that details payment. You can't just go ahead and smudge an extra $15.10 and call it square. At that point, i signed the receipt for $3.90 and submitted it to AMEX the very next day. Clearly they did not deserve the 20% gratuity. 

Just For You is a cruel wicked irony.
author: Jeff L.

description:
I wanted to like this place. The food wasn't bad (I had the eggs on cornbread with chili con carne). As I was sitting waiting for my food, a roach crawled across the table.

Needless to say, I lost my appetite and will likely not be returning to this establishment next time I'm in San Fran.
author: Nicole B.

description: Great beignets and benedicts in the Dog Patch. the area is a little secluded so you can avoid the massive crowds and long line and dig into delicious food. Outdoor seating is great on a nice day. Very solid restaurant with delicious, homestyle food.
author: Ed L.

description: Amazing place to get brunch!! Friendly staff, excellent seevice, cool vibe and sweet posters on the walls. Cozy neighborhood. Food is delish!!
author: Tomas S.

description: Bring uninteresting food that does not match its price. Microwaves, wilted greens and medicore food.
author: Mark K.

description: Best crabcakes and beignets this side of the Mississippi!  And try the longaniza, Filipino sausages with eggs.  Yum!!!
author: Jaime A.

description:
3.5

Fun and quirky little cafe in the Dogpatch area that serves up some delicious beignets, those powdery pillows of sweetness.  I was craving a coffee and something sweet so those really hit the spot.  I was a bit disappointed that for a place that serves up a lengthy breakfast menu that their coffee selection is really just brewed coffee.  Service is really friendly and the place is cozy and eclectic with their mix of sports, movie posters, and vintage world posters.  It's the sort of place you stop by on a lazy weekend for a simple brunch or a beignet fix.  Be sure to read through their snarky menu for a good laugh.
author: Pauline L.

description:
This is such a great location in Potrero Hill. We never have problems with parking and usually get there early enough where we don't have to wait.
This past Sunday was the SF Marathon, so it was not crazy packed as usual. We have a dog and there was a spot right out front that was empty when we arrived. There were several other dogs and it is always great to find a dog friendly restaurant in SF!
I have had the huevos rancheros as well as the breakfast burrito with bacon. Both have great flavor and I would get both again. Also, they have a great gluten free toast option which is always good for my friend. The service was great this past Sunday, especially considering we were sitting outside. 
However, I was pretty annoyed when I asked for a side of salsa and they ended up charging me $1.25. The breakfast burrito is already $10 and doesn't come with any sides.
I still think this is a great little restaurant and I will definitely be coming back. I have never felt so guilty eating a breakfast burrito with bacon while watching marathon runners in their 5th hour of a race run by. But I was really hungry.
author: Alisha K.

description:
A solid, completely-from-scratch, creative, organic breakfast and lunch place, masquerading as the kind of old run down dump you remember as a kid and you still see sometimes in little towns.

They carry off the diner dive act so well that it had scared me off until now.  No matter what people think, greasy fry griddle food is usually terrible - bad for you, bad for your taste buds, and bad for the planet.  I only went in because I had to go to the bathroom and they were the only place open on the block  Not being a dump-n-dash kind of guy, I thought I would order something to be fair.

The menu was a shocker - lots of stuff, local, fresh.  They make their own bread, for example, and they promise the eggs are from well treated Petaluma chickens.  For lunch there's lots of interesting stuff - po boys, hangtown fry, fresh dungeness crab salad...

It all does look a little heavy, so I settled on the lightest thing I could find, a roast red pepper soup.  The first few bites were a little underflavored.  To my annoyance there was no hot sauce so I just corrected the salt and added some pepper and... wow.  That was some damn good soup.  You know it's good, when every bite brings out a little more to your tongue, a little nuance to things, and your smile gets wider and wider.  It was one of those soups that builds a half hour smile.

The iced tea was decent too.  I know it's kind of lame to build a whole review off an iced tea, bowl of soup, and a trip to the bathroom, but I think I've discovered a new go to breakfast and lunch place and I can't wait to try everything else.
author: Gil S.

description:
Situation: Beignets. Oatmeal pancakes. House turkey sausage.

Assessment: All looked delicious.

Problem. There was just one of me.

Solution: Mix and match thanks to Just For You's extensive side selection.

The beignets are good, massive and topped with quite a bit of powdered sugar (which came into play later). They are a house specialty and worth the splurge. (plus it helps you can get just one, more than that would be dangerous).

House turkey sausage can be skipped. I've had better from the grocery store.

Oatmeal pancakes should not be skipped. They are outstanding. A moist and flavorful yet light batter that tastes even better when using some of the leftover powdered sugar from above.

And if you are digging lunch, the veggie burger is nothing memorable, but the wheat bread it comes on is (all their bread is house made).

Helpful tip: Dining solo is not advice because 1) you need someone to help you sample everything and 2) the wait for a counter spot is longer than twos and fours waiting for a table.

Fortunately there is free coffee while you countdown to those pancakes.
author: Jason B.

description: Best beignets!  Far better than Brenda's French Soul Food, and worth the three-mile walk from Polk Street.   Eggs Benedict are served on choice of English muffin or whole-wheat bread, but the Hollandaise sauce could use a touch of lemon juice.   Friendly and solicitous servers.  Great place for an afternoon breakfast.
author: Mamie B.

description:
My main reason for coming here initially was because this is one of the ONLY brunch places in SF that opens until 3 pm on a Sunday. Unheard of. (Trust me. I had to stall my friend until her wedding proposal at 5 pm that day so I diiid my research)

Anyway.

Nice, hearty portions (you won't be leaving food on your plate or going home hungry). Free coffee refills (if I remember correctly). Yay street parking close by! And a nice neighborhood-y vibe. I'm likin' it.
author: liz c.

description:
JFYC, is a place serves breakfast my way. Good portions, great tasting and not too complicated. 

Starting with the beignets. I must say that they were excellent. My friend discovered the raspberry jam they had on the table, and I will admit that I spread a little raspberry lovin' on mine and turned them into an even more sinful experience.

I ordered the eggs benedict (over ham) with grits. Hot damn they were good! The eggs weren't covered in a bland sauce, oh no. The hollandaise tasted amazing....had a little zing!

I tasted a chunk of thier cornbread, and it too was divine (and they throw in a substantial piece of cornbread, if you order one).

This place seems to be busy so come prepared for waiting (especially for parties larger than 2). And inside the restaurant, it is loud. Almost a little too loud for me =(
author: Hilda Z.

description:
On New Year's Day we went here for brunch. I wasn't surprised that we had to wait for over an hour for a table. The waitress we had wasn't overly friendly or service oriented which I know would annoy most other yelpers, but I didn't really mind because I hate the in your face style of some servers who constantly check in. The place was very busy and I could tell the staff was frazzled but doing their best to keep their cool and keep the place running.

We started with the beignets...Too much powdered sugar for my taste, but I shook some of it off and enjoyed a bite of the warm doughy pillowy goodness, but were these funnel cake cousins worth the one hour wait? Ehhh, not really.

I ordered an egg white omelet loaded with fresh spinach and other vegetables. I loved that they had various types of hot sauce. I enjoyed my breakfast, but couldn't help but feel I could have gotten the same meal anywhere in the City.

Don't go out of you way for this joint... It wasn't worth the journey or the wait.
author: Lori K.

description:
The beignets are pure happiness in my tummy! A MUST try. Best beignets I've had in the America's hands down! (And I've tried my fair share of them!)

Note the 5 Star Rating is 100% related to the beignets. The rest of the menu is good but banal and would most likely warrant a three star rating.
author: Caroll M.

description:
Stopped here for brunch on my way to the 22nd street Caltrain station. Parking was super easy and the wait for 3 wasn't too bad. They had free coffee outside which was nice on a chilly SF morning.

:: Food ::
(in order of which I liked best)

- Oatmeal Pancakes: DELICIOUS, melted in your mouth. I loved it with the with the seasonable raspberry jam but chickened out of asking for the recipe

- Beignets: 3 for $4-5, delicious and amazing portions

- Biscuits & Sausage Gravy w/ eggs: $9 the biscuits were fluffy, a bit dry but good
author: Frances N.

description:
Went here for the first time on Sunday as I have heard so many good things about this place.  I ordered a beignet which was quite good, albeit a bit under cooked.  Having spend several years in the South, I decided to really ruin my diet & order the biscuits & gravy.  I love good biscuits & gravy.

What I got were two over cooked eggs (thye had what we used to call a "barbed wire fence" around the edges) swimming in a sea of white, pasty, flavorless goo with just the barest suggestion of some sausage bits (they couldn't have put more that half an ounce or so in the dish). 

The biscuit were also pasty, flavorless & under cooked.  I ate the eggs & a bit of a biscuit & set the dish aside (though my dog did seem to appreciate half of a biscuit).

This with a beverage & a tip cost me $18.

Normally, when I have a bad experience at a restaurant, I won't return, but the menu looks very interesting & the waiters were fast & professional, so this place will get another chance from me.
author: sally g.

description:
Nice little Dogpatch neighborhood cafe for breakfast/brunch. We found the raved about beignets to be ok, not the best thing since sliced bread...there are better places to get beignets in the city. 

For bfast, I had a really good omelet special: turkey, red peppers, mushrooms, spinach and Swiss cheese - one of the best combos I've had in a while. A big plus for the cafe having longanisa (Filipino sausage) - don't find that in your average place...my wife had to add that to her order. We heard another customer rave about the French toast but my wife found them to be a little bland.

Overall, good place to grab brunch...although get here early since I hear it gets crowded on the weekends. We got here at 9:30am on Presidents' Day (a Monday) and had to wait 10 min. When we left, it was prob closer to 20 min. Also, parking can be a hassle in the area.
author: Alex C.

description: The food here is pretty good, we especially like their beniets. They were warm, soft and fluffy. Not overly greasy. Oh man we're they melt in your mouth good! I had the Crab Benny which were really good but the hollandaise was a little much and on the thick side. Otherwise the flavors were all pretty good. My husband had the Chorizo breakfast burrito. It was his first time having Chorizo and he liked it a lot. It was a freezing morning he had a hot green tea and I had a nice big cup of coffee. Their coffee was pretty good too and the guy kept it filled. I think I ended up drinking around two cups after I have lost track or refills. We will definitely be back again to try something new.
author: cherry w.

description:
Came all the way from soma, lol to have their breakfast :)
Beignets are good, large portions and somewhat reasonable prices
author: A C.

description:
We had a large group meeting here for breakfast today before a volunteer event. The cafe was absolutely wonderful to work with.  We kept going back and forth on how many people we'd have and they were really flexible. We had a reservation and sent our orders ahead of time so that we could make sure we were out in time to start our event.   I think we ended up around 20 and everyone was coming in at a different time.  They were really accommodating and even packaged up the meals for those that were late so we could take them to go.
In addition to the amazing customer service the food was delicious! The quality was really good and portions were a nice size.  Definitely recommend to anyone!
author: Tiff N.

description:
If you are forced out of bed at an ungodly hour, come get some crab benedict. They open at 8am--even on New Years Day.

And if you're extra lucky they might bring out some hot beignets, on the house. Score.
author: Leah H.

description: I would come here again for the beignets! Yum. But that is where the food ordering would stop for me.  This little breakfast spot is so fun and the artwork inside is amazing.  It also helps that the staff is super sweet and efficient.  For a vegetarian breakfast, there weren't many options.  The homefries with cheese and grilled vegetables I ordered was pretty tasteless.
author: Vanessa L.

description: I've been here twice and its far far from home. Well, the other side of town. Great place and original. I had the "hangtown fry" (oysters and eggs made famous during the gold rush)  my first time there and it was great. You have to order the beignets and the coffee is not the usual dirty water diner version, it actually has taste. I'm looking at the menu to refresh my memory and see they have Po Boys. I have to try that next time. Time to hop into the jalopy.
author: Rich M.

description:
Another wonderful brunch spot in this brunch obsessed city! My husband and I decided to try something new and were very satisfied with our experience here. All the food was fresh and delicious and the waiters were super nice.

Ambiance: Lively and bustling, which in my opinion is a good sign for a brunch place! What better way is there to enjoy brunch? This place was definitely a great place for groups and families. It had very simple yet eccentric decor, which was diner meets cafe.

Food: My husband ordered the Greg's scramble which was delicious but I was absolutely devouring my eggs benedict which I think may be one of the best I've had! We also shared the oatmeal pancakes which were perfect for the health conscious pancake lovers! The only thing that could be improved was the coffee. It wasn't bad but not great either.

Service: The waiters were friendly, fast, helpful and attentive, no complaints here :)

All in all, we will be going there again in the future!
author: Tasneem A.

description:
I'm a simple man to please when it comes to diners. All I need is thick bacon, fluffy biscuits, and a huge pile of home fries. This place is a good spot for some bacon and eggs or what have you, and the burgers are pretty good too. Although do I kind of resent having to order fries on the side.

The service is a little hit or miss, but I think they might have a lot of turnover so that's probably the reason for that. With that said, when the right people are working there it's pretty great. Prices are a little higher than what I would like to pay, but not that bad

Overall, this place is a pretty solid choice for breakfast or lunch. Try the jam on the table! It's amazing.
author: Hans A.

description:
I really like this place.  Good food, good vibe, good prices.

How much do I like it, you wonder..?

Well, let me tell you how much.

But before, I'll need you to...

BACK OFF!

YEAH YOU, BACK OFF!

AND YOU TOO!

OH, AND YOU, START BACKING THE HELL OFF RIGHT NOW!

DON'T EVEN THINK ABOUT WRITING YOUR NAME ON THE WAITING LIST.

This place is JUST FOR ME!

YEAH, ME

DID YOU HEAR??

JUST FOR ME!

NOT YOU!

ME!

*Sight*  

Ok, maybe we can go together.. 

Maybe.  

Only if you buy me a delish Bleu omelet. Hmm..perfect mix of tasty bleu cheese, tender mushrooms, healthy spinach, crunchy red peppers and artichoke hearts.

And a hot sugary beignet. Or rather 2. Or 3.  Actually, make that a dozen.

Deal?  or BACK OFF?
author: Margie B.

description:
My brain has ADHD.

I find myself thinking about the most random things.

Take this one....

Scenario 1: Your girlfriend or boyfriend is in the shower in the morning and they are almost done.  They yell for you and you take over a warm, already running shower.  

That's a pleasant experience that features a nice way to transition from warm bed into a warn shower.  Mix in a smack on the ass and you're golden.

This, I like.

Scenario 2: Same scenario as before, but instead of taking over an already running shower, they turn it off and get out.  It's now your turn to get in.

For some reason, instead of a nice and warm entry, it feels more like a damp and lukewarm gym shower instead.  It's just not the same.  

Kinda gross actually.  

Why am I sharing this?  

Consider it a PSA to make sure you snag that shower before the water turns off I suppose.

Another PSA?  

Make your way down to Just for You Cafe.

One of the better breakfasts around.  

In the SF world of mimosa and poached salmon salad brunches, Just for You is a nice change.

The chicken fried steak and beignet (how many people have to look up the spelling on that one when writing a review?) combo is key.

Transition.
author: Archie R.

description:
OK, if I try to be really objective about this place, I can only justify a three star rating.  This would be based on mediocre service, "pretty good" and generously portioned dishes, and the cash or check only thing usually doesn't work well for me.

However... my recent experience convinced me to add that fourth star.  Actually, after today's experience I would've given five stars if not for the aforementioned reasons.

Today, I realized something about myself.  As I sat at the counter, facing the exposed kitchen area, I saw three men working the stove, toasters, and prep counters.  All men.  On the wall beside the entry to the kitchen, was a sign: "Danger Men Cooking."  Cute.  

Then I realized - wow, I really dig men in the kitchen!  Seriously.  I didn't realize how comfortable I was knowing a man was in the kitchen.  ALL my life, I've been spoiled with men cooking for me.  My father, my brother-in-law, my brother, ex-fiance.  My fondest childhood memories are of my father cooking up huge breakfasts on the weekends.  To this day, he is known for his breakfast feasts.  My hips are now paying the price.

Who knew that men in the kitchen would be such a "security blanket" for me!?  At any rate, there was something so comforting for me to see/feel this today at JFY.  

Aside from the testosterone element in the kitchen, in case you weren't aware, I LOVE BEIGNETS.  And when I say LOVE beignets, I really mean, "will-fly-to-Cafe-du-Monde-on-a-whim-for-some-beignets" kind of LOVE.  And, with no pending trips to the Big Easy anytime soon, these beignets will suit me just fine. Lovely texture, perfectly sized, not too greasy, not too dough-y.  

Other than that, service is kinda spotty - not consistent.  Plus, I don't really like having to ask for more water and coffee, esp. when I'm at the counter facing you.  I appreciate the very cool vintage decor and the convenience of an ATM in the neighboring liquor store.  My other favorite here: the cornmeal pancakes.  Reasonable prices and I appreciate the menu selections - not too overwhelming, but great variety for breakfast/brunch/lunch.  Nice, hearty diner which every decent neighborhood needs.

This is the perfect place for hangover grub - well, I haven't been hungover in a looong time, but from what I remember... wait, I actually can't remember.  You'll just have to take my word for it!
author: Olma M.

description:
After becoming used to the hour-long waits at places like Mama's on Washington Square and Dottie's True Blue Cafe, the wait at Just For You is easily palatable. Once seated, we couldn't resist ordering the beignets which turned out to be a great idea. How can you go wrong with fried dough topped with powdered sugar? All egg dishes come with home fries or grits, and your choice of home baked white, whole wheat, or cinnamon-raisin toast, biscuits, cornbread or scone. 

I had the Greg's Scramble (eggs and spinach and Parmesan cheese) with ground beef - very flavorsome and served with outstanding home fries. 

A return trip to Just For You is a must!
author: Miriam W.

description:
In the mood for some home style cooking, then this is one of the places to visit in SF.  You'll definitely need to try the Beignets, these fluffy overly dusted with powdered sugar are some yummy goodness.    

The food isn't amazing, but it's good and the prices aren't too bad,  However, the OJ is a bit over  priced at $4.75/glass, it better be supersized.  I tried the cornbeef hash, which was lacking a bit of flavor, sprinkled a little salt, much better.  My partner in crime, chomped on the Two Eggs Any Style w/ Longanisa (Filipino sausage, hard to find)...being part Filipino, I'm a sucker and will give you an extra star for that!  

The place is small which I'm ok with, if you're from SF or have lived in SF for a while, you know to expect small restaurants, so I really can't complain about that.  The server was ok, but the delivery of our food was quick.  

Overall, not bad, but not sure why the wait or 4-stars.  I may need to go back and try something different.  But with brunch running later than most SF spots, quick service and decent food, you can't go wrong, especially a Beignet!
author: ERICA G.

description: There is always a wait when I go there on the weekends.  The place is pretty small, but the staff is efficient and friendly.  It's not my favorite breakfast place but it's a solid place to eat.  The food is good and fresh, the mimosa's are GIGANTIC.
author: Kristin G.

description: Stood in line for a long time for a pretty good but not fantastic breakfast.  The exception was the Beignets and the La Monde Chicory coffee.   Big portions.
author: Carol M.

description:
You know a place is great when you stare at the menu for forever b/c you truly want everything that's listed and can't make a [bleep]-ing decision.

If you're lucky enough to grab one of the 5 coveted seats at the bar, not only does it separate you from the annoyance of the front door constantly opening & closing (it's a small place and tables are cramped right up to the door), but you get to watch the INCREDIBLE symphony of line cooks that pump out each delicious order with fascinating speed & precision.  I was falling in love while watching them.

It's no wonder dealing with an irritating wait - so annoyingly commonplace in SF during weekend brunch - is just part of the deal.  In anticipation of this wait, come before you're hungry if you want to avoid turning into a megabitch.
author: Jen H.

description:
A great place for brunch... not nearly as crammed and backed up as most brunch places on weekends.

The food met the yelp expectations... the menu did not have anything out of the ordinary, but what they served was good.

The atmosphere wasn't anything special and was generally casual.  It's a long building with limited window space/outdoor seating.  I will probably come back at some point.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
This place was pretty cute.  We had to wait but that was fine..I pretty much expected it.  It did take a while to get our order placed and to get our check which was surprising to me because there is a huge wait outside...you'd think that they would be working to get us out the door.  I didn't want to be rushed but I thought it would be a little more organized. 

The only complaint that I have is that they didn't have sourdough!  I love sourdough and SF is so known for it so I was bummed.  Overall really good experience though.  The food was amazing!
author: Alena B.

description: LOVE LOVE LOVE this small little hole in the wall cafe and their friendly wait staff.  I just recently moved to the Dog Patch area and fell in love with the simplicity of this cafe with robust flavors and dishes.  I can never pass up their pint mimosas either, perfectly poured (MY SIZE) and great pricing all around.  When the weather is nice, it's a perfect little place to sit street side.  And most importantly... they make their own bread fresh and offer Gluten Free!!!
author: Kathryn F.

description: We had the creole crab cake and eggs, beignets, and hang time omelette. All delicious and great service! Definitely going back and recommending to others!
author: Dre H.

description:
Food is good. Service is ok. As with most places you've got your good servers, and then the servers that check up on you 15-20 minutes after you've been sitting there or just simply are not very attentive to your needs. I've had my share of both at this place.

That said, the food is good and worth the price. Tried the delicious beignets that my friend had been raving about. I've had a few other dishes like a veggie scramble and I left satisfied and  a sandwich.

It definitely deserves the popularity it has accrued.
author: Yvonne Q.

description:
For years I was put off by the name of this place - it's too... simple? I don't know the word I'm reaching for here. Anyway, a handful of friends worked here over the years, and by the time they had each left the place, I finally made my way over. And? I was BLOWN AWAY! I couldn't believe I hadn't come sooner. Here's a short list of things I love to order:

Blue & Greek Scrambles 
Veggie Breakfast Burritos
Huevos Rancheros with vegetarian red sauce

I sub eggs with tofu in every item and they have yet to screw it up. 

Overall, MEGAWIN.
author: Amber K.

description: The beignets are little soft pillows of happiness. It is everything good in the world.
author: Hetal S.

description:
Super good breakfast for a bit of a greasy spoon. 

Couple of outdoor sits and always busy on weekend brunch.
author: Adam Q.

description: The beauty of Just for You is that everything is focused on the quality of the ingredients. The daily specials are always fantastic and you've got to try the beignets and the mimosa's, which are 95% booze and served in a pint glass. Great servers too and a low key atmosphere. A favorite in the Dogpatch.
author: Jeff C.

description: A good breakfast/brunch place with good food, but there are many other places that offer a better brunch.  As an example, Aperto, which is nearby, had much more to offer.  Therefore, I didn't understand the wait.  Some of the positives:  free coffee while you wait, good home fries, plenty of parking, and good service.  I had their "Greg's Scramble" which was pretty good, but a little too much half cooked onions.  I haven't tried their beignets which everyone is raving about, so perhaps my rating will increase to 4 stars after I try that.
author: トモ T.

description:
Anonymous woman, let's call her Carol: Thanks for calling Jenny Craig, this is Carol. How can I help you?

Me: Um, hi Carol, I have a problem.

Carol: Well, I'm sorry to hear that. What exactly is it?

Me: I'm addicted to food. Mainly breakfast foods. 

Carol: Well, again I'm sorry to hear you have a problem. That's what we're here for-to help.

Me: Great. 'cause I want to go back to eating really awesome breakfast food but I'm afraid if I eat it everyday, I'll take it for granted and that can't happen. If you guys put me on some diet plan, I'll get thin again and then I can go back to eating my at my favorite breakfast place.

Carol: Well, that's not exactly what we're here for...

Me: I know, I know, but here me out. my waistline is expanding and just went I'm starting to go on a diet, I find a great breakfast place with these terrific beignets which I stuff with raspberry jam that's on the table and all of a sudden I'm a (happy) hot mess, snowing my powdered sugar all over my zucchini and mushroom scramble. I'm addicted to this place and I've gotta stop cold turkey. They don't serve turkey 'cause it's breakfast/lunch but they've got a badass line of daily specials which I bet could involve turkey one day.

Carol: Ummmm...

Me: I know, speechless right? They're usually super busy but I got in for a late brunch on a Sunday and they were so terrific, I managed to get 2 beignets, a 3 egg scramble, a giant piece of corn bread with warm butter and grits and I'm counting down the hours till I can do it again. I have a serious problem.

Carol: ...

Me: You wanna come with me tomorrow? You'll see what the problem is and you can correctly assess the situation then. I'm telling you, this place is addictive but the parking situation isn't bad at all so I'll pick you up. 

Carol: ...I um, huh?

It's okay. You'll like it. How could you not?
author: Jessica K.

description:
My friends an I spent about an hour waiting outside in 44 degree rain.

We loved it.

Great food, all the way 'round... and great service to boot.  I'm a total dick about any restaurant offering southern specialties like grits or beignets (being from the south, and all that).  

Beignets were unexpectedly huge, but still fluffy and delicious, and the grits were completely unmolested and yummy.  

If you aren't from the south, here's what goes with your grits: butter, salt, pepper... and perhaps mixing that together with your eggs.  Period.  It's a freakin' starch to be treated like potatoes.  No syrup.  No sugar.  It's not cream-of-friggin'-wheat.  If I sit next to you and you mix something sweet with your grits, expect to get a boot to your head, Yankee.

JFY doesn't mix in cheese or anything else with their grits.  Congrats.  It's not polenta... it's grits.  They get it :-)

Totally worth the wait, even in the rain. One of the best brunches I've had in SF to date,  Oh, did I mention the $8 mimosa pint?
author: Mark B.

description: This place is amazing! The food was incredible and the service was the best I've ever seen. I would move to San Francisco just to eat here every day.
author: Cassandra L.

description:
Like everyone else has suggested.. BEIGNETS! They make it to order. It comes out fresh, crispy on the outside, heavily snowed with power sugar, airy on the inside with a touch of buttery yumness. mmm!

I ordered the Fried Oyster Po' Boy cause a review said it was scrumptious.. and it is... especially during Oyster season. 

Everything is fresh.. the bread, lettuce, tomato, seafood. Waiters and waitresses are friendly and welcoming.

thumbs up: beignets, po boys, the people,
thumbs down: it can get busy
author: Lauren Y.

description: Right after traveling through a sea of industrial buildings, there lies a cute and hip restaurant.  My driver had told me that the fish tacos were amazing, and they sure looked good, but I couldn't resist the special.  Spicy chicken fried chicken with sausage gravy, mashed potatoes and a side salad.  Amazing.  The table to my left had the beignets and a hamburger, both which got rave reviews as well.  Can't wait to quench my appetite here again.
author: Jennifer L.

description: My co-workers and I consider this our to lunch spot. Super friendly service, very good food, and quick and efficient. When I go to lunch on a work day, I want to be in and out. They have our usual drinks to us practical before we sit down, take our order quickly, bring the food quickly and have a check to us before were done eating ("take your time" they always say, but for a working day lunch, there is nothing worse than waiting around for the check when you've got a boatload of work to do back at the office.  Jambalaya, shrimp po-boys, black beans & rice, and huevos rancheros with green chile are standouts. The cream sauce pastas are overly heavy and not to my taste.
author: Chuck M.

description: I really like this place.  Around the corner from work, so I can get breakfast for lunch.  I'm really surprised how some people can screw up breakfast, but this place does breakfast well, and their bacon alone is worth the trip.  Worth a visit!
author: M D.

description: Beignets, beignets, beignets! Fresh homemade bread and pretty much fresh everything. Staff is excellent. Will definitely not disappoint!
author: Ty H.

description:
We came here because our out-of-town friend wanted to eat eggs. I said every brunch spot will most likely be packed and we'll have to wait an hour. Especially since it was warm out. I also wanted to try a new spot. We saw the menu and yelp reviews and were sold by the beignets. 

We waited a long time. Not quite sure how long, but it felt like 45 minutes. I guess the trick is to put your name down and stroll over to the DogPatch Saloon for a drink and come back. We saw several people doing this, although one group totally lost their spot when their name was called and they were nowhere to be found. I don't get why this place draws groups of 5-8 but it took forever for us to get seated. It normally is not a big deal, but our friend had to catch a flight. 

The menu has options galore. Every imaginable breakfast/brunch item is on here. That made it hard for me to choose. The beignets were very tasty and much bigger than the ones you get at Cafe Du Monde. I give them 5 stars for these.

The rest of my food was not so great. It was partly my fault for rushing and ordering their veggie hash omelette. The filling was sweet potato, bell peppers, swiss cheese and onions. I also ordered their biscuits. The portion is so big here. Eating sweet potato and then regular home fried potatoes and biscuits were a carb overload. There was just way too much sweet potato and not enough of the other vegetables. It was a big pile of sweet potato. 

I definitely want to come back and try other items on the menu, but will definitely steer clear away from this veggie hash. Totally not what I expected.
author: Caroline L.

description: perfect venue for weekend brunch. Enjoyed the special Scramble and it was awesome. Crowded on weekends, but service is quick and friendly. Dogpatch gem.
author: Leon L.

description:
Just for You was just so cute. My friend mentioned beignets and everything else in life just didn't matter anymore. We ordered the 3/$4. I hadn't had beignets since I went to New Orleans a few years ago. I asked the waitress if she recommended the homemade turkey sausage patty or the chicken apple and she said she didn't eat meat. 

Rather than go into a whole discussion about whether or not she didn't eat it for religious, health or PETA reasons, I left well enough alone. But I still wonder how you can serve something you've never eaten. What if it tastes like crap? Can you still hand someone crap? I guess so.

Anyway, she brought out 2 beignets covered in powered sugar. They looked like pillows of powdery goodness - I wanted to lay my head down on them. Then our waitress comes back a couple minutes later and says, "You ordered 3 beignets?" Well, I didn't know that you could order them individually?! It's 3/$4! Sheesh.

They were great and I really just didn't care about the rest of my breakfast after that. I wanted to order about a dozen more to go, but knew that they probably wouldn't be good unless they were blazing hot. I ended up getting the turkey apple sausage, which was a bit on the dry side, but flavorful. My eggs were eggs, cornbread was whatever, and I'm not a fan of homefries, but they were decent. I liked the atmosphere and will go back for beignets. Oh yes. The 4-star rating is for their beignets. Food I would give like 2 stars. So maybe I should average to 3? 

NOTE: They're not Chinese, but it's CASH ONLY!
author: Ming-Jou C.

description: So, I've been back a few times, and my experiences have been better.  It seems to be one of the few places that always has cornmeal pancakes, which Tintin loves.  I've tried the huevos rancheros, and the chili scramble, and both were good.  Service is good, but the wait for a table can be obnoxious.  Good thing you can get coffee from Piccino's to kill time.
author: Seong P.

description: Pretty disappointed in my follow up visit here.  The catfish filet was undercooked and had a strong fish taste--not well-prepared like it was last time.  The potatoes were undercooked and hard to eat also.  Only good biscuits and gravy and a nice server saves Just For You from a two star rating.
author: Jack K.

description:
My partner and I had been wanting to try this place for brunch, so we decided to brave the Saturday breakfast crowd. We waited about 40 mins for a table, but it was sooooo worth it! 

I'm a texture whore when it comes to my food. I like it to have substance, crunch, something I can really sink my teeth into. The CORNMEAL PANCAKES, ordered with crispy bacon, are to die for. Seriously! Try these and you won't be disappointed. You may want to splurge further and order real Maple Syrup. I was too cheap to shell out an extra 2.50 for syrup, so I settled for the fake maple syrup on the table.

My sweetie ordered the Huevos Rancheros with New Mexican Hatch Green chile sauce on top of corn tortillas. Now, I'm a native New Mexican, and I'm really picky when it comes to California's preparation of our beloved chiles, so I was a bit skeptical. 

JFYC...you nailed the chile sauce! My partner had to fend me off with a fork cause I could not get enough of the hella hot green chile goodness. It reminded me of "home" and I cannot wait to go back. Nice touch to offer corn tortillas instead of flour. I'm always suspicious of huevos rancheros served on top of a flour tortilla with salsa. yuck!  

 Thanks for a great meal and for the great service!
author: Michelle S.

description:
Really fantastic food with funky retro ambiance.  

I like this place!  The walls are covered in 60's psychedelia posters advertising local music.  It's really fun to check out what's hanging.

The food is pretty phenomenal.  They've got awesome breakfast food like grits, omelets, grits, pancakes, grits, beignets, grits, etc...  Oh, and I definitely recommend the grits.
author: Ivan L.

description:
So the food here was great. But while reading the menu i came across this little gem and was SOO offended I will never spend money here again:

"What's grits? It's that pasty white stuff... like you had in prison."

That's a direct quote from their menu. 

Oh wow so now everyone who eats of likes grits is in prison. That's so thoughtful. I guess that's where my grandma got the idea. 

I know they have an edgy style and there are jokes all around but this was just in very very poor taste.
author: Alexandra H.

description:
After a work mate and fellow yelper pointed this place out to me, I just had to go. He said that it was so good that he went a few times a month!

I wasn't the least bit disappointed. After getting there a bit on the late side (around 11:30am on a Saturday) we were surprised to find that we could get a table for 4 in about 10 minutes! And the place isn't big. Sure, it's not as small as you would think at first glance, as there are a few extra tables in the back that you can't see from the outside, but it's still not big. Nonetheless, I was surprised to get a table so fast because there was  small crowd gathered outside, waiting to try out Just For You. 

Eventhough the (probably new) hostess had very little idea what she was doing, we found our table and the waiter came by quickly and took our drink orders. It was crowded we were still about to place our orders in about 7min, and our food was out in about 20min after sitting down. 

I had Greg's Scramble with Chorizo (about $9). It was amazing. If you haven't been here before, seriously, start with this. You don't have to get it with Chorizo as there are tons of options, ranging from spinach and mushroom to all sorts of meats. It was fantastic. Oh wait, I said that already. It doesn't matter. It's was brilliant. Other people wanted by food. 

Skip the grits and go with the home fries. Ok, maybe I'm a bit bias as I don't really like grits, but the home fries are fantastic. 

The Beignets (about $4) are donuts with a layer of powdered sugar. I was a bit disappointed that they came out AFTER our actual food had, but that didn't stop us from eating them. They were great. Soft and moist and obviously very very sweet. I would ask to make sure that they come before because they would definitely relax your palette a bit before your real food.  

All in all, Just For You is fantastic and I can't wait to go again!

Note that they accept CASH ONLY.
author: Mariko F.

description:
Cool spot, comfortable atmosphere, friendly and happy waitpersons. Food was good, eggs done right and outstanding home fries. Sign by kitchen reads "Caution, Men Cooking"...could that be why the food was done so well?
I work nearby, but not near enough to walk. Parking is a challenge.
This will become a regular spot for me.
author: Ron U.

description:
Beignets, Beignets, Beignets.  Light, Crispy and COVERED with powdered sugar...A great start to a yummy brunch!  Came here with some good friends and we definitely had some awesome conversation starters about this place.  For instance, the posters around the walls were awesome!  Check out the poster of the pink Power Ranger.  Her name was Kim (thanks, Kimmie for the quick trip back into time!).  Best of all was the poster announcing the Alcatraz reunion (Sad that I missed that one!).   

Anyhoo, yes, the beignets were great.  The mimosas were served in a pint glass to the brim and the coffee stayed warm and refilled.  To top it all off, service was friendly, even in the midst of all the hustle and bustle during a Sunday brunch rush (say that 5 times in a row!). 

I had the Frittata of the Decade.  Wow...flavors were bursting!  Zucchini, mushrooms, onions, garlic, cheese...I would've liked the eggs a bit more fluffy, but nonetheless, it was good.  The side of grits was good too: add some butter, salt and pepper.  Oh, and throw in some pieces of Chicken Apple Sausage (or bacon for that matter) and you're golden!

The chili scramble was massive.  The cornbread was moist (mm...moist...) and thick...A good hearty meal!  

Just For You Cafe is not for bird-eaters...it's quite a heavy brunch, so prepare beforehand and wear your best stretchy pants!
author: Jennifer L.

description: I've been here a few times, usually during an off hour when they're not too busy - and during those times, the food is absolutely wonderful. Totally defines 'comfort food'. However, today I came in and they were a little more busy - the main entree I bought was okay, but the bigness, not so much. Ordinarily I LOVE their beignets but I'm guessing since they were so busy (and possibly understaffed, I only saw two people in the kitchen) they were not paying attention to how long they were cooking. I definitely know they were not cooked long enough or the oil was way too hot - raw in the middle!!! No Bueno, definitely not okay, hence the bump down to three stars. However, they were very understanding, comped us the cost of the beignets, and made us a few more fresh ones (more cooked through but still obviously yeasty in the middle). I'll still come back, but probably during my usual time, when they're not busy. Make sure you rip one of the beignets open and check to make sure it's not raw if you come here for them!
author: Rhea S.

description: They were SOO friendly and I got the big breakfast burrito with veggies!! It was flawless! I'll definitely be back :)
author: Katelyn B.

description: quirky menu, but everything was delicious. The beignets were huge...compared to the ones I've had before in NOLA...but they lived up to the hype. They have some outdoor sitting and it seemed pretty easy to park around that area. Would definitely recommend it.
author: George M.

description:
5 stars all for one thing: BEIGNETS!

Just go to this place for the beignets! They are sooo delicious! You can order three in an order or just one (but I dont see why anyone would just order one), and I seriously can eat all three by myself, in less than 5 minutes! They are that good! So go! Go to Just For You Cafe and order the beignets. And think of me, yours truly, while you are indulging in heaven on earth.
author: Cheryl S.

description: Great, diner style food! Home cookin!
author: Peter S.

description:
My friends and I are brunch people; we like brunch and, for a while, we kept going back to our favorite stand-bys.  No longer, we are on the hunt for new brunch spots...

Just For You came up as a top pick, so even though it was a bit out of the way for us, we got there very early to beat the crowd (and boy was there a crowd as we were leaving).  The place is pretty small - probably seating 20-25 people max.  We didn't have to wait too long (even after having our name called without the entire party being there - we were next on the list), but we got there at around 10:45 (practically breakfast time).  

I was STARVING by the time we sat down, and I made a beeline for the savory menu items.  There were a few specials (an eggs bene and a few other items), but the Mexican menu items - breakfast burrito and huevos rancheros - called to me.  I couldn't decide, so the waiter suggested I get the huevos rancheros because the spicy red meat sauce was delicious.  And, of course, we ordered beignets for the table.

Our beignets didn't come out until after our brunch entrees (we had to remind the busboy) which was a bummer since we were hoping to dig into those before our entrees arrived.  With both appetizer and entree at the table, it was tough to decide which food item should get cold.  For the most part, it was the beignets - Sandy H. prodded us into eating as many beignets as we could before they got cold.  Too late.  :(  The couple of bites of hot beignet that I had were good, but they weren't the delicious, melt-in-your-mouth ones that I remember from New Orleans.  But, alas, this is San Francisco, not New Orleans.  I enjoyed my huevos rancheros - can't say I'm a huevos rancheros expert but the spicy red meat sauce was very tasty.  

We got an unfortunate table in the back of the restaurant between the kitchen and the front of the restaurant and right next to a loud ice machine and soda refrigerator.  Not ideal, but not a real ding in my book - but if you're picky about that kind of stuff, you may want to let them know.

If this place was around the corner from me, I'd probably be a regular because despite the mediocre to average service, the food was solid and the prices were reasonable (brunch with coffee came to ~$12 including tax and tip).
author: Wendy L.

description:
I went here for the first time with two other (hungover) people on a busy Saturday morning.  We must have arrived during a lull in the morning rush, as we only had to wait about 5 minutes before we were seated.

Our waiter was dressed in an outfit that I would imagine a Court Jester might wear, but he was super nice and prompt.  I don't generally have impressively high standards for food, but when our dishes arrived, the breakfast was nothing short of amazing.  The beignets were piping hot, and the closest thing to eating a loaf of donut-bread as you'll get to experience in this lifetime.
author: daniel v.

description: Favorite brunch place in the Dogpatch.  From their coffee to their beignets, everything was good.
author: Patrick S.

description:
Mexican food in San Francisco?  Outside of Mission district?  Impossible you say?  I found a Chorizo breakfast burrito worthy of adding to any "best of" list for Mx food.  I am so glad we went there today.  I have been missing San Diego's scene for a couple weeks now, and I've been forced to cook my own stuff-- which is delicious, but takes a lot of work.  Who's got the time to be awesome in the kitchen when kids are hitting each other and jumping off the counters?

Just me sometimes.  But, I am always in the mood to find the satisfaction only a burrito can often provide.  I had no idea I'd find it at this artsy looking place in a quiet neighborhood so close to 3rd st.  Gladness.  Tastiness!  More awesomeness.  

The burrito looked actually small when she first gave it to me, but at first bite I knew it would be a challenge to finish it, and I almost lost the game.  But, it was so good I would have been sad to leave it on the plate.  Luckily everything went so swimmingly well together, that I enjoyed every last morsel while I suffered the pangs of over filling my stomach.  

Taste:  Chorizo was nice and flavorful, not too spicy, not too greazy.  Went very well with the fluffy scrambled eggs, salty black beans, jalapeño salsa, lots of real cheddar cheese, and a just-under cooked tortilla (sometimes that works well.)  Good flavors all around melded together to be a whopping bonanza of balance and each bite led me into deeper territory within my own appetite, I was actually scared to go there.  We made it out alive.  

Decor:  Top notch kitsch and rock stardom.  All kinds of colors added to the snarkiness of the quotes all over the place and theme of the artwork.  

Environment: Nice natural light entered through the bay windows, so bright that some ladies who looked like real housewives of New Mexico kept their sunglasses on the whole time.  The staff were all very nice and knowledge filled.  Low levels on the music, but I could feel the bass in my face.  

Food:  Yum.  We also had grits, HOMEMADE cinnamon raisin toast (of which I got a loaf to go), biscuits, and we had no room for the Beignets unfortunately...

All in all:  more than five stars.  I will be back.  No dinner though, yet...
author: Joshua K.

description: we had a good time here! good service and food.   duck confit is not my favourite bec of the duck and the sourness of the sauce. but my friends ordered fresh toast and scrambles and they are all good. this brunch place has a very good vibe.  saw lots of artists here!  LOL
author: Shuting Z.

description:
I really wanted to like this place.  I really did.

However, searching for a vegetarian brunch, I chose to go with the veggie burrito.  I thought it would come with all the standard burrito items - beans, cheese, rice, etc. + the veggies listed on the menu.  That was just not the case - it came with a ton of sour cream and not much else.  Honestly terrible food.

My friends, on the other hand, really enjoyed their breakfast choices... and I did like the beignets!  

Should I give it another shot?  Or is it just not for me?
author: Gretchen S.

description:
I'm determined to try every soul food/comfort food joint in the City and Just For You is a place that's been on my list for awhile.  Therefore, I was undoubtedly excited to come here especially since I've been jonesin' for some beignets!  Obviously, we started off with the beignets which were of course smothered with powdered sugar, but were also swimming in a pool of butter, which I did not like so much,.  However, they were still yummy, but its kinda hard to f%*k up something fried.

Before going on about the food I want to comment on the vibe, very cool, laid back, local feel.  It kinda felt like I was somewhere in new Orleans, perhaps Magazine street.  The service was efficient enough, not great but OK.  One of the girls working there never smiled which made me a little uneasy.,

Moving on, I got the grits with biscuit and fruit.  I know not exciting, but remember we had some beignets so I was a little full.  Also, at our table was the tofu scramble which look amazing.  My grits were pretty basic, but very creamy.  And as for my biscuit it was very fluffy, but not crispy enough for me, think it should have been in the oven a little longer.  Overall, I liked this place not loved it but I am definitely willing to come back to try other thing on the menu like the fritatta or breakfast burrito because I saw other people eating that it looked delicious!
author: Molly M.

description:
Beignets!  They are so good here that when I went to New Orleans, I was a little disappointed.  Seriously...Cafe du Monde does NOT compare.  They are light and fluffy and covered in piles of powdered sugar--sort of messy.

The staff here is on their game, and they had a Scoutmob coupon for 50% off, which was excellent.  I recommend egg dishes, biscuits, obviously beignets, the chicken apple sausage, and pancakes.  I am a huge brunch fan and I'd come here all the time if I lived closer.  Sometimes there's a little bit of a wait, but I recommend waiting, and that's coming from a very impatient person.  Do yourself a favor and come here immediately.
author: Julia D.

description:
AH - Just for you?  No! JUST FOR ME!!

The beignets here are worth the wait.

Then again, so are the pancakes - 

And the veggie omelets - 

Oh, and the BOMB Crab omletes!!!

So, Please, I implore: don't go here.  I tend to think I don't need any more people ahead of me in line next time the beignet craving kicks in.  :)
author: Athena S.

description: late sunday breakfast in the dogpatch...afternoon crowds and a wait...name to clipboard and standing fifteen to twenty minutes...coffee pump outside not free...charged later after table...starting the afternoon right with a pint of mimosa...behemoth champagne and orange juice $eight...near perfect fifty/fifty proportion from taste...requiring some time to finish...instead of cumbersome size, best to sell champagne and juice separate, and let patrons self mix smaller pours?..browsing menu of standard breakfast, burgers/sandwiches and traditional...blocks of home fries looking handsome...cornbread appearing enormous...eggs benedict sauced and pretty....can't decide and requesting suggestions....breakfast burrito?...taking it the "old way" with cream cheese...simple breakfast burrito and no sides included...cutting center to find overfilled with cream cheese...lot of white and chorizo chew...simple handheld burrito eat...splashing of cholula, tobasco, tapatio, crystal, etc...hot sauce face-off...crystal the saltiest...cholula providing best taste....tobasco for extra kick...tapatio the middle of spice, tang and salt....splash of cholula before each bit...oozing white cream cheese...bit too much white and overpowering entire burrito...best to take the breakfast burrito the "current way"...finishing with a beignet...single $one.seventy-five order to share amongst four....all non-sweet-tooth...heavy on the powder sugar...thick dusting and don't inhale too close...*cough*...empty airy center...crisp thin outer shell....intense sweet melting of powder sugar...tap off for next bite...don't let size fool...mostly hollow and simple beignet...$twenty per person meal with a drink...
author: Hen A.

description: My favorite spot for brunch.  Like anywhere else in the city there's always a bit of a wait but they serve you coffee while you're waiting and the line moves pretty fast.  This place and the crowd don't feel pretentious.  It has that diner feel with excellent food.  They come in decent portions and are served fast.  The wait staff is always helpful.  I like their cowgirl, cowboy, egg benedicts, beignets.  Their coffee is okay but not to die for.  I bring people here and none ever had anything bad to say.  Five stars.
author: Kelly M.

description:
Oohhh... this is the place to BE when a hangover strikes.  Hello rainy Sunday morning filled with a headache and nausea!  My friends and I decided to stay in bed until later in the afternoon... around 2PM, a little late for breakfast? Yes.  The place was jam packed, but the wait wasn't too bad - around 15 minutes.

The foods:

Beignet: Oohhhhh wassup! I love me some beignets... I hadn't had one in a WHILE and was pleasantly surprised by this little gem on the menu.  We decided to split an order of three, yummy yummy.  I loved the light fluffiness. I even ate the whole thing! Yes, they're huge... don't you judge me.

Greg's Scramble with chicken apple sausage: Mm Mm... I got this with the home fries.  This was hearty.  I liked how sweet the sausage was, especially with the cheese on top.  I would definitely get this again, maybe even with a different meat option.  OH! I got it with a biscuit... strike that, this ish comes with 2 biscuits!  These were definitely AMAZE, especially with the preserves on the table...

Overall:  Hell yeah, whenever I'm in the Dogpatch (and the previous night was ROUGH) I'll be here in the afternoon having my breakfast and wearing my sunglasses.
author: Isabella O.

description:
This is one of the best breakfasts I've ever had in the  bay area.  Don't miss out on Greg's scramble, or you'll be sorry. Very sorry.  Fluffy eggs, right amount of veggies and cheese, and perfect portion size. Be sure to add a pancake on the side; oatmeal or corn.
It's all good.
author: silvertongue- p.

description: Despite working around the corner, I've avoided coming here due to a presumably long wait for a table (always crowded). I finally saw an opportunity during the holiday vacation, when half the city is out of town. Even so, just to be safe, I called my order in for pickup instead of trying to brave the waitlist. I placed my order at 11:04 and was told it would be ready in 10-15 minutes. I arrived and paid at 11:17, then stood outside until my lukewarm box was unapologetically handed to me at 11:40. Probably should have just waited for a table.
author: Leslie F.

description: Delicious breakfast food. Very much stick to your ribs. And very popular.  Wait wasn't too bad. The host was fast, communicated well, and got coffee orders filled while we waited.  The only thing I didn't like was that due to its popularity, it was hard to hear and felt squished. But overall, worth the wait.
author: Kelly M.

description: So I went here with my gf (she is a food science major) and while we were looking through the menu she pointed out that the paragraph on the menu about the quality of the food has a bunch of cop outs like "if price allows" in it. Then she orders apple juice for $2.75 and they brought her yellow gmo apple juice from a farm that uses bromide as a pesticide. So we threw five bucks down and walked out and went to another restaurant.
author: Matt N.

description:
Can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet.  I've been going since they were up on Potrero Hill and like the new spot too.

They do a great job of making the food light in the sense that it's not leaving you feeling ridiculously full and greasy.  The staff is pretty chill and it's especially nice when it's a nice sunny day to go sit outside.

The only drawback for me is that it gets so crowded on weekends so I try and go during the week more...
author: Gene X.

description: The location is in a cute neighborhood, a mix between industrial and residential. It has a rustic feel and a strong art interior. The food was ok. We tried the beignets which would have been spectacular if it were a little less greasy. The eggs Benedict was... Ok... Where ever I go I try the eggs Benedict because it reminds me of home with my family, this one didn't quite bring me home. It was served on bread instead of English muffins, which would have been a great twist on the eggs Benedict if there were something great about the bread. My son had pancakes which he enjoyed. He's four. I felt bad for the server because he was running around like crazy. It adds a different feel to your experience when your watching someone run through the service. We didn't get a chance to ask for more napkins, (again, we were eating with a four year old. Napkins are essential.) or another roll up. I don't see myself coming here again.
author: Joann V.

description:
The JFY staff acknowledged my gripe about the ridiculous wait and expansion concerns. So I am upgrading this place to 4 stars as result. I do appreciate places listening to customers. I will have a 5 star waiting for them when they come out with a new location. Or setup a mobile Beignet cart outside to feed waiting customers. 

Great food.
author: Lawrence S.

description: Everything is delicious. The red flannel hash is my favorite, but it is only on the menu sometimes.
author: Mrs. E.

description: Yummy! I ate breakfast for lunch here on a Friday.  My food was tasty and the location and atmosphere were fun.  The biscuits were a bit dry, but with some jelly still really yummy.
author: Christy L.

description:
Alright... knockin' off the dust on my keyboard and brain, I thought I should do a couple of reviews! I been eatin' here and there, and one of the most recent joints was Good For Your Cafe, and I DID NOT leave unsatisfied! 

Me and the GF wanted some breakfast and wanted to try to hit up a new place, so a friend / fellow foodie suggested this cafe, said it was "hella good". We found it pretty easily and with parking right in front (it was 730am, so naturally we were the early birds, no lines, no wait, smooth service). So we get in, sit down, and READ the menu, while at the same time wiping off the drool that would fall onto the menu. The menu is extensive and very appetizing to read. After a few minutes of, "what do you think?", "I dunno...?", and "this or that?", we finally made our decisions. 

I got the chili and scrambled eggs, and the GF goes for the huevos rancheros, and since this place claims to be "the best beignets in the city", we ordered 2 for desert (or is it dessert?) Both dishes were plentiful, no need to eat more than your share, lest you plan to roll out in a wheelchair. 

So I get my dish and dig in... awesome! The chili is beefy with the right amount of tang and a little spice. Underneath the chili was chopped onion, and then the scrambled egg, which was seasoned just right, and with perfect fluff. Then there was the cheese melted all over, which was good enough to make the dish dee-lish (I mean who doesn't love cheese, right?). However, what really brought the dish together and put on another level to set it apart from all other scrambled egg dishes, was the homemade cornbread lying underneath this savory concoction! The cornbread was fresh, fluffy, and sweet, which worked as the perfect companion with the tangy and subtle spice of the chili. The entire dish reacts wonderfully together, and if left me full and ready for a nap (I normally don't wake up this early). 

The GF's plate, the huevos rancheros was also well done. The sauce that went with the eggs had just the right spice, no need for Tabasco with that sauce!
