However, the tortilla didn't really do much for the plate, and of course you need a tortilla for a plate like this if you plan on calling it "huevos rancheros", but then again I am being bias in my assessment. What can I say, I grew up on homemade huevos rancheros by a Latina mother. Either way, both dishes were great. 

Finally, after feeling like we're going to explode, we remembered our beignets... should left some room, but then again, Im'a trooper! So we got our beignets, super fresh and moist from the kitchen! There was plenty of powdered sugar, so additional toppings are purely gratuitous... so I added a bit of maple syrup... and then... AWESOME! After that, I was done... D-U-N-N! 

So, as you can see, I was blown away by the food. Now a quick word on the environs of the joint. The place is decorated with a homely feel. The walls were colored in light beige. And there were also framed posters from what appeared to be the owner's favorite movies. They had one of Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid, and another one of Clint Eastwood's western movies, and other assorted prints.  However, like most breakfast/brunch joints in the city, they're small, so no reservations, just long lines.  So if you want to be able to get in and relax and enjoy individual service, get in EARLY!!!!
author: Jo R.

description: Staff is very friendly and the menu is full of good soul food. Prices aren't cheap, but the food was much better than I expected so I suppose that's alright. Looks to be a regular diner, but the menu is a step up in my opinion. Oh, they also have some entertaining decor, even in the bathroom. "We aren't asking you to be Michael Jordan, just to get your paper towel in the trash." I'd definitely visit again if in the area.
author: Krystine C.

description: Excellent beignets. They are hot, light and fluffy, unlike at Brenda's where they're actually quite hard. (Sorry Brenda, I still love you guys.) Their free, fresh, home-made strawberry jam at every table also goes well with the beignets. Everything else, however, is just mediocre. (Actually, my poached eggs were below mediocre since they were both overcooked.) On the bright side, huge portions.
author: Jonas T.

description:
Reading down all the raving reviews here I wonder whether I was just here on an off day or something.

Firstly, the service was great, and the environment is fun. But, the food was really poor. The beignets smelled of stale oil and were a little dry. The eggs were underdone, oily, and again smelt of stale oil. The chicken apple sausage was burnt, tasted a little odd, and after encountering a big piece of bone/gristle I gave up. The home fries were undercooked (the potato was still hard) and again the nasty stale oil smell and taste. Finally the toast was really, really, dry, as if it had been sitting around for hours and just retoasted.

I really want to give this place another try, because it does have a lot of things right, but I'd need the memory of the very poor food to fade first.
author: Paul F.

description: The beignets, smoked salmon omelet, Eggs benedict over crab cakes were delicious. Had my first taste of grits with butter and they were good too.
author: AndyBoy V.

description:
Got here at 9:30ish on a Sunday morning. We waited approximately five seconds for a table. The seating is not that comfortable. The food was great though, and the service was fantastic. Prices were reasonable for SF and there's a Muni stop right outside (T-line). 

*Did not see the restrooms.
author: Green Y.

description:
This place defines brunch. If you're an SF brunch person, then you already know this place. Homemade breads and the beignets...oh my those beignets.

Come on over, put your name on the clipboard, grab a cup of joe and enjoy the neighborhood. See you on the weekend.
author: Darin A.

description:
This place is the cutest little dine-in cafe in the Dogpatch. The service is excellent, the beignets are what they're known for, and the decor makes you feel oh so happy inside. 

Oh and the coffee being free is a HUGE +
author: Kerry Z.

description:
Ahmmm, they now have gluten free bread (or wheat free, which I guess is more technically correct from a gluten contamination perspective)!

If you're gluten intolerant or allergic or just like to limit your intake of gluten, you can try the French toast, any burger or sandwich, or even eggs benedict on the weekend with the GF bread.

I can't think of a single SF diner or cafe that offers fresh GF bread, can you?

It is delicious.
author: Abendigo R.

description: This is my "go to" spot for brunch, as both the food and service are consistently better than average . . . at least this has been the case for me on all visits. I recommend the beignets, mimosas and convincing the person you are dining with to order two other dishes and share them family style. Its even better, when you can convince them to order two things that YOU really want i.e. buttermilk pancakes and eggs bennie, a side of crispy bacon, beignets (3) and mimosas. Oh and don't be afraid to substitute your fruit for home fries. :)
author: JC D.

description:
Solid 4-star brunch joint in the dogpatch

pros: 
relatively short wait for brunch in the city, 20mins at 12:30pm, 
great fresh baked goods - BEIGNETS (must have), toast, etc, 
decent prices dishes range from $9-$11 and are filling, 
Great home fries, usually these are over-deep fried but well done here with just one crispy side almost like a half hashbrown

cons: none really, place is busy so servers aren't the most attentive. 

overall - $45 for two people including coffee, plates, beignets, tax and tip
author: Noah P.

description:
Great breakfast/brunch place.
Show up a little earlier and you won't have much of a wait.

The servers are nice enough, more no nonsense when it gets busy.
Not your typical white shirt khaki pants staff. Fun decor.

We ordered the famed beignets, however when they came out, one was not entirely cooked so they just picked up the entire batch threw it away and along came another plate. I was sad to see the good ones tossed out =(

My group ordered a variety of dishes.
The Eggs Blackstone stood out, and everything else was fine.

The bread for their toast was dense and hearty.
Potatoes...ok, not much on the flavor end.

Solid breakfast place and a definite bonus was the easy street parking.
author: Angel L.

description: Everyone else is right: the beignets are really good -- light, airy, and sweet. I also had an egg scramble with chicken, pesto, and cheese, as well as a side of potatoes. The portion size was good and the potatoes were tasty. (Some place's potatoes are plain.) The staff was very friendly and accommodating.
author: Paul L.

description:
Wonderful. Breakfast was the perfect start to our Saturday. We took some bignets to go, and nibbled on them all day long. They were soooo good. They serve pint glasses of mimosas by the way. 

We didn't wait in any line either. Bonus!

YUM! LOVE!
author: Jewel N.

description:
How did I basically live at the Mission Bay Avalon for 2yrs and not know this existed?!

A friend & I shared the mini-donut-esque things..beignets. BOMB. And I had a poached egg with grits (sidenote: "like the kind you ate in prison" - as soon as I saw that description, I knew it was my kind of place) and cornbread. No complaints, though it was kinda a carb/sweet overload but that was my bad. My friend got a chili scramble or something and it had cornbread in it. Never seen that before. He ate all of it despite being hungover so I'm guessing it was pretty good. Would definitely come back here, if just for the beignets. 

Our waiter was honest with his recommendations and overall the service was dec. The place is a little dinky so not really somewhere you go for the ambiance.
author: Lilian W.

description: I have been coming here for such a long time and have been loving every bite!!!  This place is a gem. A must for a great meal. Great food and great service.  Well done!!!
author: Jay S.

description:
Great brunch after a rowdy night.  

Fun, funky vibe.  Coffee comes fast.  Mounds of delicious food.  I loved the beignets.  

Be prepared to wait.
author: Brianna C.

description:
Great place for a weekend brunch. I wanted eggs benedict without the meat. So they replaced the meat with thinly sliced mushrooms and spinach. It was just perfect. 

The beignets are heavenly. Definitely try that. 

The potaoes are okay.
author: Akta A.

description:
When it comes to breakfast there are So many options in the city and this is by far my favorite.
Gregs scramble = add zucchini, mushrooms and chicken apple sausage and go home happy
Beignets = best in SF
Grits = yum
Coffee = strong and free flowing

They also have steak, catfish and a list of other tasty treats.
Kid friendly and outdoor seating.
author: Joseph M.

description:
Solid bruch place.  I've actually been here on multiple occasions, but for some reason I always have problems searching  it though the Yelp! search engine or on Yelp! mobile.  It wasn't until recently that I was on their website that I realised there was a link on their main page.  

I was here this past Thursday for a late lunch, which turned into a brunch since I ordered the chorizo and eggs.  I always order their beignets.  They also have very solid burgers, best ones in the area. Parking can be a bit tough at times.
author: Stacey L.

description:
Blech! Why do people like this place? I had been looking forward to the beniets but they tasted all oily and, well, awful. My wife's chorizo scramble was also really greasy, and not the good kind of greasy either.

Can't recommend this place at all.
author: Chad H.

description: I love, love, love this place even though I've only been here twice.  You must try the beignets here!  The service is great!  The staff is fast and friendly.  There often people outside waiting but people get seated surprising fast (compared to other places I've been to).  The food is delicious and affordable.  Parking is never a problem if you are willing to walk for about two blocks.
author: K L.

description:
Great breakfast/brunch; we particularly recommend the frittata of the decade and the bleu scramble.  Also love the grits.  Oh and their home made bread (try the cinnamon raisin).

We especially loved that we didn't have to wait to sit and eat on a Saturday. Servers are efficient and friendly. 

Definitely a neighborhood gem!
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
First impressions are fun. It was a great Saturday morning - sun was shining and people were out after having so many cold days. This seems to be a popular spot especially for the locals in the neighborhood. There was a sign in board but the wait didn't last too long and the cool part was that they had a cart outside with cups and hot coffee.

We sat at a community table. One couple was very nice and go all the time.

So on to the food....... I had eggs, a pork chop, grits and biscuits. I was excited that they had grits - not too many places serve it. They were made very well; eggs were cooked perfect to my liking; pork chop was too thin and therefore ended up being overcooked. I won't have that again. The biscuits........ were wonderful. They tasted like biscuits my godmother would have made in the country.  Coffee was good. 

My friend had eggs with lots of goodies including oysters. It was rich but very good. I wouldn't mind having that during another visit. 

Their menu has many choices. Our neighbors had an omelette with chili that smelled really good. Might try that next time.
author: C R.

description: Such a cute little restaurant! Its right down the street from my little brothers place in SF, so whenever I go to visit him, we always come here! Weekends can be a little busy and the wait list gets pretty long. Staff is super nice and friendly. The posters and pictures on the wall are awesome, very entertaining to look at. Food is good. The lemonade is to die for, super fresh and not too sugary., My brother and I always order those little pastry puffs with powedered sugar on them (i think they are called benigets or something like that...?) Also, the scramble with chroizo is very good. Pricing of items on the menu not bad considering it is SF. Definitely my go-to breakfast place whenever I'm in SF, espeically when I'm hungover...
author: Margaret C.

description:
So yelp gives this place four stars. I give it barely two. 

This is just your friendly "we're trying be southern because we have beignets, biscuits and cornmeal pancakes, but we are really just hipsters with overpriced mediocre food." The beignets were decent the second time around - the first time I bit into one it was completely raw in the middle. Luckily the service was good so they didn't get upset when I asked them to get us new ones. As for the cornmeal pancakes - they were just that - cornmeal pancakes. Nothing special. I think the highlight of the meal was the biscuits. Very moist, fluffy, buttery and delicious.

Would I come back here if I was being held hostage? Sure. Not for any other reason. But I do think the 2 star rating says it all - Meh, I've experienced better.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
BEIGNETS - Out of this world good. Pefect balance of salty/sweet and it is so chewy. The powder sugar makes it light yet it is a sweet treat!!

The rest of the breakfast stuff is just OK. A bit over priced if you ask me but come here to share the beignets. There's usually a wait but staff is very efficient to you updated on the wait.
author: Maggie C.

description: "Early bird special" (which ends at 830am) is a pretty good deal, especially for the city.  Beignets are good if you want something sweet. And the Chili Scramble is hella bomb!  Haven't had a bad meal there. I go there several times a month.  A great place in a up and coming neighborhood.
author: Ian P.

description:
Not bad, not great

Notes

1. Try the beignets
2. Avoid the far right back corner area
3. Usually plenty of street parking nearby!

Food was pretty good for brunch, with typical brunch cafe items, at relatively reasonable prices. Service wasn't terrible, but also not particularly great. The place was busy, we get that, but it's not that hard to be slightly more present beside a table. All in all, not bad, not great, but still recommended as an alternative stop.
author: H H.

description:
I love breakfast food. I would like to have breakfast food at all meals - but alas, sometimes I have to eat like the grown up that my age tells me I am. Just for You is breakfast heaven.

My eating partner and I were in Boston recently and there was a stand with a guy selling fried dough. So we got in the line to try. It was super gross - we threw it away. The beignets here are fried dough that are super good. So good I don't want to order anything else. But I do.

I've had the cowgirl and just the eggs with some bacon - enough for two meals!

BIG PLUS: When I order green tea, they will give me soy milk if I ask. You have no idea how many places look at me like I just asked them to kill their mother when I ask for soy milk.

Attentive waiters and delicious breakfast food!
author: Alicia C.

description: Love this place! Went recently on a Saturday and got seated right away. Had their beignets and crab cake with eggs. Both were delicious! I'm always looking for a brunch place that isn't boring and like all the other brunch places in SF and this is it! The staff is friendly and efficient, I'll definitely be returning!
author: Margit H.

description:
My favorite spot for breakfast and comfort food. Feel like pancakes? Get the Cowgirl Breakfast meal. Or if you're like me and prefer the classic eggs and bacon, no problem. And of course enjoy bottomless coffee. 

At this little greasy spoon there is a sign, 'No Cell Phones' Kind of cool when you don't want a lot of chatter going on. It's encouraging in fact. Kind of like 'Leave work at the door' you're eating. 

This dive may seem a bit rough around the edges but the food makes me feel cozy inside.
author: Charlene K.

description:
My friend recommended this place as the best breakfast place in the Potrero area. We got there at 10ish and there was already a long line. We decided to walk around the block and came back in 20min, and finally got a seat. It's a pretty small place, but comfortable and sitting outside on a nice sunny day is definitely pleasant =)

There's a lot of variety on the menu, I didn't know what to pick. Everything looked so good!! In the end, i decided on the eggs benedict that came with bacon & tomatos. IT WAS DELICIOUS!!! My friend got the one with crab, but he said it wasn't as good as mine =P Also got the fresh grapefruit juice, which was very refreshing and yummy as well. Definitely would like to come back to try everything else on the tempting menu! 

Advice would be to COME EARLY cuz the wait after 10 will always be long!
author: Louisa L.

description:
I went here for the first time with a few friends and I was all set to order the chili scramble when my friend spotted someone eating a plate of what looked like pure awesomeness. She kindly asked him what he was eating, and he responded that it's not on the menu, but was recommended by the wait-staff. The Christmas!

The Christmas is a bunch of corn bread with two of their sauces poured over it - a red sauce (meat or vegetarian options), and a green sauce, then topped with an over easy egg! It may not sound like much, but both of these sauces included vegetables good stuff in them too, and the whole thing packed a lot of flavor (and spice!). The whole thing was nice and filling. I suggest you try it out!

We also had the beignets (which are kinda like french donuts), which as other yelpers have already said, are awesome! Service was good too!
author: Jeff Y.

description:
Attention Grits Lovers:  this place has some good creamy stuff!  I just needed one pat of butter..... heaven in a dish.  I sat at the counter as I was a single - entertaining to watch the kitchen staff rock it with the short order madness.  It was really impressive.  The waitstaff was very nice and tried hard to work together, but in such a small space it seemed that many were stepping over eachother to do the same thing. 

A few complaints:  I asked for my scone to go, and ordered chocolate chip on the advice of the server.  I was given a cranberry one on my plate with my eggs.  My coffee cup remained empty for a good ten minutes before I decided to leave instead of enjoy another cup of chicory-laced goodness.  Only when I began to pack up myself to head out was I offered a refill..... and I was at the *counter*, next to the register.... you know, where about 3 employees were standing at any given time.  

Also, it was as hot as Hades in here , but I'll chalk that up to the unseasonably warm October weather and the major BTUs coming out of the kitchen, rather than lack of climate control with the HVAC.
author: rebecca b.

description:
The scrumptious prosciutto scrambler special, truly made me feel as if it was just for me.  This was the first time I had beignets, beware of flying powder sugar with a rowdy laughing table of six.  These New Orleans donuts were very tasty, but were also much larger than I had expected!  One serving of three can easily fill the brunch donut appetite of two.

If I like this place so much, why only four stars?

I can go to the post office and buy a .39 cent stamp with my VISA debit card, but can't charge the $16 for a tasty breakfast!  It's one thing when a small business puts up their little "$10 minimum for credit cards" but our tab was over $70!  Begin accepting VISA/MasterCard, begin getting a 5 star review from me.
author: Anthony B.

description:
Historically I have not been a regular brunch eater.  Brunch was something that was for special occasions or when friends came from out of town.  This has all changed over the past year with my monthly SF visits and their proximity to Just For You Cafe. 

The food is great.  Whether you are looking for breakfast (served all day), a sandwich or burger you can't go wrong.  They do make their own bread (which is also for sale); I am partial to the cinnamon/raison.  Hint: You can request "thick slices" for extra bread goodness.  Plate portions are well sized so there is no fear that you will leave hungry.  I have yet to try the famous beignets but those are next on my to-eat list. 

With food this good, do expect a wait to be seated on the weekend.  It is also not uncommon to find the place bustling during the weekday mornings as well.  If there is a wait, put your name on the list that hangs by the front door.  Historically, I have not had to wait longer than 20 minutes. 

The one downside to the restaurant I would say is the service; it doesn't always live up to expectations.  I have certainly had worse but I have also had much better.  Your order will be taken quickly (know what you want and be ready when the server arrives) but it's not unusual to not see the server again for a long while.  On my last visit, I sat at the counter and my iced tea glass sat empty for about 15 minutes even though the cafe was not overly busy.  Not a huge deal but disappointing. And definitely not going to affect me from returning!
author: Bridget A.

description:
It was a very specific craving, impossible to fulfill: I wanted a huge plate of comfort food, and I wanted to go enjoy this huge plate of food with my toddler in a place that was not my kitchen. With waitresses. Date night with my daughter plus pregnancy cravings? Not a recipe for success.

My husband found Just For You by googling "comfort food," and the minute he read the menu to me, I knew where I was going. They had me at "hushpuppies." 

We got there, scored rock-star parking, and I entered with my toddler in tow. Here was the real test. Because you know the only thing people hate more than toddlers on a plane (I'm tired of these motherfuckin' toddlers on my motherfuckin' plane!) is toddlers in a restaurant. And the "no stroller" sign scared me, because sometimes the stroller is the easiest place to feed the child... but we didn't have it with us and I bravely entered the establishment.

The waitress/hostess could not have been friendlier or more delightful. I stressed that I didn't want to bug anyone and she found me a great little private spot in their back room. And magically, my daughter behaved almost perfectly, eating happily and then strolling about in a friendly fashion, stopping to "chat" with various patrons without being intrusive if I do say so myself.

Anywho, here's the information you need if you don't have a toddler: Huge. Plates. Of food. Crabcakes. Hushpuppies. Amazing fries. I mean, as I type this, it's blustery and rainy outside, and just the memory of the warm, heart-meltingly delicious crab cakes warms my soul. Love the atmosphere, the attitude, the art, and the food. Can't wait to go back.
author: Amy K.

description:
This was awesome. Gluten free French toast are tops! Must try for breakfast for those that are gluten intolerant. However please note that they are not Gluten free but rather serve gluten free products. The are used by all products gluten and wheat contaminated.

Long wait but worth it
author: Pilar M.

description:
1) Get here before 10 a.m. (for weekend brunch) in order to enjoy "Just For You" and not its evil twin "Just You Wait."

2) Order coffee.  

3) Order giant mimosa.

4) Remember they only take cash and run to the ATM in the liquor store next door.

5) Order one beignet as a brunch appetizer, or three as a brunch appetite killer.

6) Finish with Poached Eggs and Toast; what else does one need in life (besides veggie sausage).

7) Satiated, enjoy the laid back, neighborhood vibe.  Read the fun signs.

8) Depending on how many mimosas consumed, either go forth and be productive, or go forth and return to the fetal position on your sofa at home.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Okay so this is the 2nd breakfast that I had with TB this week.

I suggested Tselogs but he said hed take me here instead.

I missed the Longgonisa on the Menu last time I was here, so I told TB I want to order this instead, I saw the crabcakes too...TB knows....so he ordered both for us and of course the Beignets.

Servers are great, food is great and its nice having breakfast with TB again.
author: Malou C.

description:
BEIGNETS!!! 

Okay. The end. 

Victoria C. and I have been here twice now. The first time, we only got their beignets to go because we were meeting up friends for lunch, and were starving, so we made a pit spot.  This time, we were ready for the line.  

The breakfast will put you in a coma. It is SO good... and you get a good amount of food... and the signage/decorations on the wall are simply amazing. A mix between hipster and local. Love it. 

Stay away from their biscuits if you can, they give you two and it is 1.5 too many, they are heavy.  All breakfast items look amazing, but we had the scramble (Greg's?).  Arrive early to avoid the crowds, or come after 1:30pm, after your hangover has subsided. 

BEIGNETS!!!
author: Lisa L.

description: Have a restaurant where every time you finish eating there, you say, " Wow, that was just so damn good!" That's Just for You Cafe for me. I even hesitate to post this review because I'm not sure if I want y'all making me wait even longer on the weekends! Try Greg's Scramble. It's awesome.
author: Tom F.

description:
This place is great. The food is very good. There's usually a few daily specials so make sure you check out the specials on the menu. I've only ever had some type of egg dish when I've gone but they have been consistently done well.

You can get fruit instead of potatoes or whatever carb comes with your meal. I usually get the grits; add a bit of sugar and I'm good to go. You get the normal selection of breads but you can also get cornbread which I had for the first time on my last visit. It's a big hunk of cornbread and I almost didn't finish it. But it was some good cornbread and I don't have the opportunity to get cornbread often so I powered through and finished. They have homemade jam/preservatives for each table; this most recent visit it was blackberry.

There's usually a good wait on the weekends some come prepared if you're a late riser. They usually have some coffee outside for you while you wait though. They bring the food fairly quick so aside from some people not having the sense of mind to realize people are waiting outside the tables turn pretty quickly. But if you have a large group you may have to wait as the space is limited inside and it's not ideal for large groups.

The only negative this most recent visit was the decaf coffee. It just tasted old and weak. I'm no coffee expert but it was not good and it left a horrible after taste. 

All in all this is a good breakfast/brunch spot and I will stop in often.
author: Paul B.

description:
Only 1 out door table and we needed the outside table because I had my small long hair dog with me. But it took longer to get a seat for this reason. This place is pretty packed and the inside is quite small as well.

Thankful for their gluten free options. I scarfed my food down. I'm sure if I was just because I was starved though.
author: Angela C.

description: This was pretty good and right by my apartment. It wasn't necessarily mind-blowing but all the food was quite good, the staff were friendly and attentive, and it had a great selection on the menu. I'll definitely be back... regularly.
author: Bo J.

description:
Good place to eat.  It is Southern inspired with their beignets, filled with tons of powered sugar.  I've been to The Cafe' Du Mond in New Orleans.  The Southern doughnets here were pretty good.

Over all I was not super inpressed with the meal and the prices, but I loved the people.  You really go here for the atmosphere and the cool people.
author: Michelle M.

description:
This place has a huge brunch/lunch menu, and though they have some cajun/creole food (beignets and po'boys), the majority of the food on offer is standard American fare.

I tried the shrimp po'boy and though good, was not impressed.   The whole thing didn't meld together.  They picked bread that was too chewy on the inside (instead of light and fluffy) and not crisp enough on the outside. Shrimp was good but there were only 6 pieces in the sandwich (for almost $10 I expect it to be stuffed with shrimp not layed out individually where I can easily count how many).

I also tried the fish and chips.  The fries were good and so was the fish, but the fish batter was soggy and kept falling off.  For me the key to fish and chips is the batter so a big thumbs down here.  Especially since no vinegar was available at the table.   The tarter sauce was pretty nice though - had lots of pickle relish in it.  And the portions were huge - 3 fish fillets.  I couldn't finish.

The highlight of the menu has to be the beignets, and I would go so far to say it is the sole reason to eat here.  For $4 you get 3 huge beignets dusted in sugar which will inevitably find it's way all over your clothes.  Well worth the sacrifice though.
author: Jean K.

description:
One star is for beignets and mimosas, but that's about the only paositives this place has. We had some family in town visiting and thought we'd take them to a place with a neighborhood feel to it. 
Boy were we wrong. The service was lacking to say the least, particular the guy with suspenders and piercings who was blatantly rude to us. He literally told my girlfriend to  "go fight it out yourself" with another party that was waiting for a table. They  randomly brought the check to us while all three of us were still halfway through our dishes. Only after they brought the check did waiters start coming by the table every two minutes asking whether "everything was alright". Clearly, they were trying to get us to leave the table since they had others waiting for it.  I used to work in a restaurant that was usually quite busy so I get how this works, but it was completely out of line they way these folks went about this. Did I mention that my girlfriend's frittata had raw egg whites oozing out of it?  I had the eggs and chorizo and its nothing to write home about. Do not recommend this place.
author: Rick C.

description:
There seem to be some haters of this place. Stay away if you are.

I'm from New Orleans. The Beignets work, as well as they can without the clay-ey Mississippi water (M I crookedletter crookedletter I crookedletter crookedletter I humpback humpback I). So there.

Coffee is pure dinery luxury. Deelish. And free refills.

$5.25 for 2 eggs, 2 toast, 2 bacon and coffee, and it's 2 blocks from Caltrain. Take your hipster bike down to 22nd st, park it, have a decent breakfast, then train on down to Apple or Oracle or Yahoo.

And, just every now and then, have the hangtown fry.

The place is fab-tizzle. Worth the trip. You'll be back.
author: Glen M.

description: Not only is the food amazing (the owner is a chef, and demands only the best ingredients), but the service is friendly and attentive. Even when there is a line, they do a great job of keeping things moving and trying to minimize your wait time. Also, the cooks are super fast, so even if they are busy, the wait for food is never excessive. Have the beignets and chicory coffee, or a pint sized mimosa (fresh grapefruit/Cypress Mimosa is the best), or delicious fresh juices (some organic) are another great option. Things not to miss: Chilaquiles and Corned Beef (both are specials, so get 'em when you have any opportunity), New Mexico Green Chile sauce (made with Hatch chiles and taste like the real deal according to my friends from New Mexico. It can be SUPER hot depending on the batch of chiles, so taste with caution if you are sensitive.), Reuben Sandwich on Rye or Huevos Rancheros. Some more of my favorites are the Oatmeal Pancakes (wheat free!) Cobb Salad and the house burger, which I get on Gluten-Free toast (keep in mind this is not a "gluten-free" facility, so cross-contamination is always a possibility). Not super-expensive like everywhere else in SF these days and they have a great vibe and comfortable atmosphere--so don't bring your attitude, and tip generously! They appreciate their regulars!
author: Alyce K.

description:
Great food, worth the wait!
Loads of kitch here-posters and signs talking about having a good attitude; the staff does! Seems to be trying for a Southern/Louisiana theme-I am not well enough versed to say they pull it off, but the food was great so not really a concern.
The line was long though we did not get there until 1:30 and they would not seat a partial group (2 were there early). We understood this once we saw how small it was inside and they were full right up until closing.
We had several things:
Beignets--this was the item most reminiscent of LA (not the city.) Though they were a little doughy and not as light as some, they were good (Fat and Sugar!) :)
Biscuits and Gravy
BLT with Home Fries
The biscuits were great-not sheet goods, but actual individuals and tasty! The milk gravy slightly sweet (as it should be) with good tasting sausage.
They knew what I meant when I asked for my BLT bacon to be limp (and it was). The homemade bread was toasted on one side (inside) and really nice crumb.
Our friends had:
Special-Italian Omelet
Pancakes, eggs, bacon and corn (cake-it has sugar in it) bread 
This was our first venture into the Dog Patch and we enjoyed ourselves. This is another solid lunch/brunch place that we would visit again.
author: Simon D.

description:
came here for some good hangover food.  yes it was a good choice.  we got the hangtown fry to share and an order of beignets.  My friend and i was stuffed.  The order of beignet comes with 3 beignets covered in sugary goodness!!! not to mention they were huge!! 

The hangtown fry was delicious.  i love the bacon they add to the scramble eggs.  It definitely took care of my NYE hangover.
author: JY L.

description: Great staff who are quick with a joke or a recommendation.  Food was prompt and tasty.  Coffee seemed to almost have a little cardamom or some spice in it, which is really the only knock I can think of.
author: Buck M.

description: Love this place! The beignets, corn beef hash special, and heuvos rancheros are delicious. Great service, great food, funny signs.
author: Tina K.

description: I just enjoyed a delicious breakfast of oatmeal pancakes while sitting in the sun at "Just for you cafe" in dogpatch. Although , the wait was a little longer than I would have liked it to be my wait was was made as short and pleasant as possible by the staff, especially Kat. Thank you !
author: Shelley R.

description:
Ok this is my first Yelp review ever! Which is a shocking surprise to a lot of people since everyone knows I pretty much eat every meal out.  Yes that's right, I'm really "Kitchen Challenged" and my motto on that is well, you have to eat to survive so you might as well enjoy it right?!  I have been to hundreds of SF restaurants and while I am an avid Yelp user I have yet to give back to the community that I have taken so much from!  So it's time to change that and get my Yelp on so here goes:

I sat down at Just for you Cafe with two friends as I declared I am going to write my first yelp review on this place so come on Cafe impress me! I loved the menu options.  Great variety, nice bread selection you have the standards white, wheat, etc but also biscuits, scones, or cornbread to choose from, where do you see all of those choices for no additional charge!? 

Next pleaser was that they let me modify my scramble.  I love to modify anyone who has dined with me knows this.  Sometimes I modify to the point where I am ordering something so completely different its like a whole new menu item, well they let me do this at Just for You, so if your like the Sally from when Harry met Sally type like me then you will love this place. 

This really cool looking server took our order and then he disappeared and then this place started to loose it's charm.  We had a different server through every step of the dining process which I guess could be cool because then you could pretty much ask any of the serves for things but the challenge was actually getting one of them to come to the table after they dropped off the food.  I was having a painfully difficult time trying to get any kind of drink refill so that was an irritation. 

Ok the real important part: the food.  The food was decent.  I really liked that they had pepper grinders on the table, so you have have free rein of how much pepper you want to add and not give your poor server a sore wrist trying to grind pepper on your food when you don't tell them to stop right away because you really like a lot of pepper- that's me ;)  That being said the food was not so excellent that it did not need a ton more spices like pepper and hot sauce so nothing to write home about. The portions were filling but not out of control so huge "I can't eat for the rest of the day" sizes which is nice.  Because I like to be able to go out to dinner later.    

Tip: I hear this place can have a long line but we got there around 2 so I think the brunch crowd was thinning out so if you can wait that long without starving I say go then.
author: Marlene S.

description: Great food - friendly service - BLT on home-made white bread (or wheat if you prefer) was substantial with flavorful tomatoes and beautiful bacon. YUMM! Thanks for a delicious lunch.
author: Laurie Anne B.

description: This review is for dinner (writing a review for their breakfasts is unnecessary, everyone knows they are awesome).  I've been eating breakfast at Just For You for a decade or so and I love it.  Dog Patch is becoming unnervingly posh and expensive.  Four Of us had tried to get a table at Piccino at 6.00 but were turned away from an empty restaurant and told there was a 45 minute wait for to eat at the bar.  We know we look a bit unusual for new SF so we went off to find a little piece of old SF that would love us!  It turned out that Just For You was open for dinner, I've been wanting to try it for ages, but have been unsure which evenings they're open.  There was a table, we sat down and loved the menu, there was something for meat eaters, fish eaters, vegetarians and vegans.  Food arrived quickly, it was fresh, cooked perfectly, tasty and the portion sizes were refreshingly filling (another happy change from SF's new normal).  The prices are amazingly reasonable.  I can safely say that the food was the best I've had in Dog Patch for ages.  The wine list is limited, but the food more than makes up for it.
author: Emma C.

description:
From the menu:
"Hangtown Fry - 3 eggs scrambled with bacon, oysters, and onions. If this doesn't cure your hangover, you'd better just go back to bed."
yes, it is as awesome as it sounds. Whoever thought of this deserves a medal. it's now one of my favorite food/dish ever!
author: Albert L.

description: I love JFY! I love that their fare is hearty and well-priced, and the quality is about what I would expect of a diner/cafe, but maybe kicked up a notch. Their beignets are my FAVORITE! Light, airy, yeasty, and dressed to the nines in powdered sugar! I top it with jam and I'm set! It's also close to the ballpark so you can totally hit up this spot for breakfast and then walk, MUNI, or bike to the ballpark for a day game.
author: Ava J.

description:
You can't go wrong when a cafe is made just for you.  This is the go to spot whenever you feel like have breakfast for lunch.   

I was not a huge fun of the beignet's but they are good.  It was one of those things you have to try once.  Be warned, these things are HUGE.

The Greg's Scramble with chicken apple sausage is delicious.  I usually saturate my omelets with ketchup,  but this scramble had a variety of flavors making me want more.

My favorite meal here so far is the chicken sandwich special.  This chicken sandwich is topped with pico de gallo that gives it a unexpected twist.  Pair it up with a baked potato and you'll leave happy and full.
author: Danny P.

description:
Beignets *and*  a breakfast dish that could have been named after me? One bite of the Crabby Bennie and I was hooked.  It was worth it, even if my brother insisted on calling me that the rest of the weekend.

We'd heard it's very popular, so we showed up at the ungodly hour of 8 am on a Saturday morning and got a table right away.  I tried not to snicker too much as we left, walking past the huge crowd of folks waiting.  It was difficult.

Homemade bread to die for, beignets, and crab options made it well worth the trek to Dogpatch.  Do it, but go early, and you won't be disappointed.
author: Jenn G.

description:
Brunch brunch brunch! Nom nom nom! A visit to Just For You cafe in the Dogpatch neighbourhood on Sunday morning set me up for the perfect day. What more could you want, apart from a) amazing bluebottle coffee (from nearby bluebottle cafe) whilst you wait for your table, b) great company, c) lovely weather? Oh, that's right....BEIGNETS!

This Southern-style brunch joint has a guaranteed looooooong wait on the weekends, but it's worth it for the beignets and cornbread alone. Seriously - the tagline 'fresh, fluffy pillows of perfection' aint lying! Admittedly, not the most healthy start to the day, but oh so delicious.

A breakfast feast of eggs, chicken apple sausage, home fries, cornbread....and beignets....will definitely set you up for the day, and wont break the bank!
author: Melanie B.

description: The service was average. The food however was very tasty, well done, I will definitely go again & again for the food. Love the corn bread! :-)
author: Robyn M.

description:
I tried coming here on a Saturday a few weeks ago, based on a friend's glowing recommendation, only to be driven away by the long wait and cash-only policy.

Today: success! Apparently 11:30 on a Wednesday is a much less popular time to belly up to JFY. I felt like I could have ordered 95% of the menu and been happy, but I limited myself to a beignet and the Cowgirl breakfast: eggs, two pancakes, and a choice of link sausage or bacon.

The beignet was astounding. I'd been expecting a delicate little powderpuff, but the powdered-sugar-coated delight that arrived at the table was gargantuan. Still warm from the fryer, the beignet was the perfect partner for the raspberry jam kept on the table. Together they made the world's most fantastic jelly donut.

My cornmeal pancakes (they also have buttermilk) were also amazing. Again, I was surprised by the portion. I'd been expecting some silver-dollar-sized pancakes, but these were more like salad-plate-sized ones. And the well-browned flapjacks resulted in mouthfuls of toasted corn flavor, made even better with a drizzling of maple syrup.

If I lived in the area, I'd be a regular. As it is, I'll be dragging my SF friends here as much as possible from now on. :)
author: Julie K.

description: So I was craving beignets and I heard that these beignets are as good as Cafe Du Monde.  So I ventured out with my friend to see if this is true!  I've never been here before but my fellow Yelpers say it's a great place to eat.  So naturally I'm incline to believe this is true-  and WOW !!! YES it is!!!! The food is so yummy and just plain wholesome.  I had the Greg's Scramble with egg whites mixed with organic veggies and nicely paired with their homemade toast!  Who could ask for anything more?   And the "poinsettia " was deliciously refreshing! A cran-raspberry juice with champagne! No better way to enjoy a " little something " in the afternoon.  Our server "Kat" was incredibly nice and welcoming!  So why? A 4 star-rating? Because the first server that first seated us  seemed bothered and disinterested and luckily she disappeared! And "Kat" who truly deserves a 5 star-rating totally made up for our first negative impression.   Funny enough, I never got a chance to taste those beignets.  Completely unaware that they close shop early around 3pm and we were there way pass 3pm.  By the time I ordered the beignets, Kat informed us that the kitchen was closed!  Seeing that I was bummed out, Kat  handed us a coupon for "free beignets on the house"!!!!!! Awesome Service and scrumptious food.  A great reason to come back!!!!
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
I love these ladies!
Big delicious plates of home cookin' at it's best! I normally order the cowgirl because sometimes.....I wish I was one. Don't use your phone....seriously, they will drop it in a pitcher of water while you stare stunned, then preceed to finish your delicious meal. Hey, it is what it is, right?
author: John A.

description:
Craving an oyster po boy and everything else was closed.  Late hours on a weekday are helpful.  

Boo hoo hoo!!!  No moh oysters said the waitress.  I opted for the shrimpy po boy and hush puppies -- on a fried kick.  It was good, but I've had better po boys and hush puppies.  Unfortunately the food was underseasoned.  

Perhaps they're better for brunch.  The SO had been there before and enjoyed it, so I chalk it up to being an off night.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
My new favorite brunch place. 

The Huevos Rancheros with green sauce is my go to, and the beignets are actually really good. Unlike those flat pieces of oil bread that they try to pass off as beignets at Brenda's, Just for You's beignets are closer to what beignets are supposed to be - light, powdered-sugar coated pillows of doughy goodness. Scrumptious.

Long wait here so be ready to listen to your stomach growl for a while.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I have been trying to get in here several times but always saw a line out the door on Sundays for brunch and got discouraged. BUT this time I woke up early (9 AM) and called in to ask them the wait time. They don't take reservations but by calling in they can estimate the wait time for you. And since I live down the street, why not go here for a Sunday brunch. 

I love their menu (also there is a link to their website so peruse it before you show up so you know what to get once you sit down). Once you show up if there is a wait outside write your name down on the clipboard, grab a complimentary cup of coffee off the cart outside the front door and get comfy while you wait. 

I didn't know they have a bar but since I am going here alone it was perfect. I got sat right next to this handsome cute guy named Aaron and we started up a conversation until we got our food. [shout out to Aaron: Thanks for making my first time here so much fun!!!!!] The atmosphere is really comfy and homey so don't be afraid to talk to the person sitting next to you or the table over. Very friendly and patient staff who will take care of you, what more can you ask for? 

The food is fabulous!!!! I ordered the Cowboy which is nothing more than a French Toast breakfast w/ two eggs over-easy and three bacon strips. Crispy thick bacon, so yummy!!! Then of course I got a small bite off of Aaron's Beignets, so yummy! Who can pass up light fluffy donuts w/ powdered sugar on top? If you can't eat it there then take it to go. And a cup of coffee to wash it down, endless cup of coffee, something I need in the morning to wake me up. 

This is a place you go to to enjoy good food, good conversation, and to relax on a Sunday morning. No rush so take your time. You might find street parking a bit difficult but I live down the street and riding the T-line isn't so bad. I'll definitely make this my Sunday brunch place, as long as I can avoid game days because that will pack the place up. 

Enjoy!!!!
author: Nana R.

description: Went here for breakfast. Not a very long wait on a Sun. morning Charming staff, good food, a nice variety of items to choose from, cute neighborhood. loved it!
author: Robin A.

description:
What's happened to me? I used to be hhhaaaahhdd (hard). A rough mo-fo unafraid to fling vitriol in 7-11 Super Big Gulp sized portions at all who crossed my path. Now, here I am, splayed out like a sloth after a 32 inch run, on the sofa writing a glowing fucking review for yet another local eatery. 

Ya ya, Potrero Hill/Dog Patch/3rd Street/Bayshore is so hot right now. It's true, cool kids with and without their cool new bikes and/or babies were thicker than oatmeal but the J4U staff hummed with wry efficiency. 

I love efficiency in a diner, especially on Sunday faux-morning (1PM). All the things you want minus all the frilly crap you can do with out. Beverages filled, topped off without query, sides and add-ons delivered with a friendly briskness that bespoke the Beaches of Normandy level traffic hitting the joint. 

Corned beef hash was good with plenty of textural variety that makes hash fun (fatty, crispy, meaty bits all in happy coexistence a bit like Malaysia but that's a different story), biscuits were reasonable and plentiful, gravy was spot on with a pretty perfect viscosity (dippable but not runny) and meat bit ratio (well flavored but not requiring additional chewing). The wing-woman who makes it all worth while's crab cake Benedict thing was good; solid, earthy, herby with a pinch your nose good hollandaise well slathered. 

The bar lacks bag hooks and the stools are oddly wide spaced, no elbow jostling here. 

It's good. So there, and the garage sale around the corner was offering free hugs. Awesome! No, not. But the rainbow glitter suspenders for a dollar were just the icing on an already calorie rich brunch. 

Word to your mother.
author: Milk N.

description:
Their beignets are seriously to die for; a perfect treat that melts in your mouth.  Their pint-sized mimosas have me hooked on this place.  Well, their amazing dishes aren't so bad either. :-)

This is my favorite place to go on the weekends for some afternoon breakfast/brunch eats.  I need to make it out to their happy hour where I think I've heard their pint-sized mimosas are half off!  Oh boy, I sure hope its true.  

On weekends, this place is PACKED! Expect a wait, but it sure is worth it.  When you get there, there is a list posted next to the door outside.  Jot your name down and write how many are in your party to get on the list.  I don't think I've ever had to wait more than 20 minutes, which may seem long, but it really is worth it when you have time.

Can't wait to go here this weekend!
author: Jaime L.

description: Absolutely adored the frittata and homemade biscuits, excellent service!
author: Sarah M.

description: Just for You Cafe is now my favorite breakfast place! Everything is delicious ! Beignets are so yummy, I even ordered some to go.   5 stars breakfast & lunch place for sure :0) they also serve beers & mimosas
author: Stella R.

description:
I don't wait in line.  I just can't.  I did this past Sunday though and I'm glad because Just for You Cafe has a very good breakfast menu.  I can really sum this review up with, "I love their Biscuits!"  I enjoyed the grilled catfish even though I think of it as the one fish that needs to be fried as much as possible. 
Not sure if I'll ever make it back to the Dog Patch for breakfast, but if I do I'll be trying the beignets fo sho.
author: Corey V.

description:
I love Just For You -- whether it be for breakfast, lunch, or dinner. I now live in the neighborhood and have tried all three. I agree with many other reviewers that it's debatable as to whether JFY is worth the long waits for weekend brunch, but, if you're in the 'hood or get there early, the wait isn't such a factor. 

There's nothing pretentious about this place; they aren't trying to be fancy. The one thing that I most other reviews here miss is that JFY is part of the slow food movement: they make their own bread; they use high quality meats; they don't use transfats, etc. It may look like a diner, but you will not come away with that greasy, unsettled stomach feeling. The food is authentic and good -- just like your (great) grandmother might have made. :-)
author: Mark V.

description:
I've been eating breakfast at JFY coming on 15 years now.   This place has maintained a great quality of food, tasty, fresh and served hot through my entire tenure.  Even after moving locations from Portrero to Dogpatch, almost without a hiccup.  

Beignets are tight, american breakfast is supah tight, huevos and many of the other egg dishes are also way tight.

Some people gripe about the vibe, mainly because Arienne takes NO MESS.   That means turn your damn phone off and enjoy the company and your meal.

JFY FTW!!!
author: Richard A.

description:
Stumbled upon this cafe while wandering around Dogpatch, and stopped in for a quick bite to eat. There was a line, but the wait was fairly short and our server came right away to take our drink orders once we were seated. He was friendly and gave recommendations on the specials. I wasn't terribly hungry so I ordered just one of their famous beignets, and hubby had the corned beef hash. The beignet is exactly as advertised - light, fluffy, pillowy doughy goodness! I wasn't quite expecting it to be as large as it was, but it was delicious down to the last bite. The hash was also very good, as was the fresh carrot-apple juice. I found that the sweetness of the apples balances the root-y taste/texture of the carrots very well. 
They were also very accommodating, as we had two friends who wanted to join us after we had already ordered, and they made sure to move us to a table of four - while still seating the people who had been waiting in line.
author: Ji K.

description: Good. Beignets were yummy but not the best I've had. Cute place. Good breakfast. Solid.
author: Kelly S.

description:
Great neighborhood spot!  Friendly staff, strong coffee, fluffy beignets, excellent, diverse menu for meat-eaters and vegetarians alike!!  Easy to park, cool decor, fun place to bring out-of-towners!
A few downsides:  tends to be a wait in the morning (although coffee is available), tables are a bit crowded for parties larger than two, tofu scrambles are a little greasy (but still super yummy), sausages are not fresh (but other meats are excellent), and at very back table sometimes the onions from the kitchen are enough to make one cry.
I bring up the downsides only as small areas for improvement.  Overall, this place is an eclectic gem and worth the wait!
author: Sandra H.

description:
NOMSSSSSS!!!!!!!!

This place is SOOO good!  The beignets, yes, were awesome.  HUGE, and awesome with powdered sugar kissing my nose on a warm Saturday morning.  Sweet, hot and light these marvelous beignets were.  Great with the jam jelly in a jar at the counters... jelly donut, anyone?

I had the Eggs (something).  Their variation of Eggs Bennie anyways (3 ways), but mine had bacon and tomato (one of my favorite combos).

I had the Eggs Bennie on homemade bread (that's right).  Thick white toast (although now I know they do cinnamon raisin bread, I shall have it on that next time to satisfy the sweet savory cravings of my tongue (which I suppose implies I will be there again. :))

Anyways, the hollaindaise was awesome, thick, and perfecto- wonder if they use lime?  Savory enough, not too heavy, nice acid.  Good balance.  They poach their eggs really well too.

Down home damn good goodness.  Umm... what else.

Oh, grits were okay. Nothing exciting.  Like boring oatmeal in a bowl with cheese on top.  You can get that or the homefries and I recommend going with the homefries- red potatoes, skin on, pan fried and perhaps roasted.  Delish.

OOH. They have hangtown fry.  I want. I want.

xxoo
author: Tracy L.

description:
This place is right around the corner from my house and I am a regular. The food is so amazing with huge portions. I suggest the breakfast burrito and the beignets (YOU MUST TRY THE BEIGNETS!).

The price is equivalent to the quality and amount of food you get. The service is pretty good. Not amazing but they are definitely friendly. I suggest trying this place on a weekday if possible because there is always a long wait on the weekends.
author: Melinda B.

description:
Grub-IN! And just a short walk away. Y'all suck for keeping this a secret from me for so long! They have stevia sweetener and whole wheat bread for the healthy girl in me, but they stay true to someone's southern roots as well with the perfect grits and creamy hollandaise sauce. The green-eyed baby daddy loved his crab cake benedict (and he used to live in New Orleans) and my southern granny would have been proud that I ordered and loved the grits with my bacon and tomato benedict. 

The staff was great as well. I guess I was expecting Mission-style ennui, but everyone was very accommodating, even of our friend's stroller and and bambino. 

I am going every weekend if Will T lets me! I'm dying to try the oatmeal pancakes.
author: Gretchen T.

description: Who knew that this place has the Best Pecan Pie Ever? Did I say "ever?" Yes, ever! The pie here is why God, in Her infinite wisdom, gave us pecans and pie crust. Yum.
author: Tom R.

description:
On one particularly fine "snow day" from work (wherein leaking ammonia closed our offices) some very hotstuffs and I decided brunch was in order.  It was gorgeous out - scorching actually; and we had no work!  Woo!
We came for brunch, got a good chuckle over the signage and menu quips, ogled a bunch of kind of hot giant bikers, and ate a bunch.
Tasty vittles folks - recommended.
author: Jennifer D.

description: I loooove their beignets! So fluffy and powdery! That was my favorite part of my lunch.  We shared a shrimp/oyster poboy which was ok.  I hardly tasted the oysters.  I'd definitely go again for the beignets tho!
author: Christy A.

description: 4.5 stars.  The only reason I didn't give 5 stars is 1.  The bathroom is gross.  2.  The 'mickey mouse' pancake.  I posted a picture--it seems a very loose interpretation.  Anyway, I took a long bus ride from upper Haight and it was worth it.  Short wait on a Friday, but no problem.  I ordered the Hangtown Fry, and it was AWESOME!!!  I would definitely return next time I visit SF.  Also loved all the clever signs hanging around the restaurant.
author: JP i.

description:
Ack!  Just returned to this place (unfortunately with a friend from out of town).... I don't know what happened, but the food was of a completely different caliber.  The biscuits were clearly frozen, the toast brought w/ the meals was cold... the MEALS were cold.  
The staff were wonderful, but the food was just plain lousy this time around.  I don't know what happened, but it makes me UNhappy.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Worth the hype! We had been scouring yelp looking to find THE hottest breakfast spot in the Bay area to kick-start our vacation and we did not leave disappointed. 

The outside and interior are nothing to get excited about but it is quite quaint and cozy inside. But most importantly it smelled and looked fantastic. Be forewarned my friends....cell phones are NOT welcomed here! 

We kicked things off with 3 beignets between us. These are NOT munchkin sized. More like softball-sized. Extremely hot, fresh and deliriously delicious. I highly recommend slathering on the raspberry jam even if I couldn't quite convince my companion to do the same. (She is a bit crazysexycool) 

I went with the Cowgirl breakfast (what an emasculating name for a manly meal) including buckwheat pancakes. The late, great Buckwheat himself would have declared them O'Tay! Pancakes fantastic, eggs good but the bacon....oh the bacon is to die for. 

She had the Fritatta of the decade and loved it. Said it tasted like a delicious pizza. The bacon was so good that my lovely companion, a self-professed vegetarian, had 3 slices and easily could have knocked out 10 tasty pieces!!! As a side note, ALL bacon in Cali is delicious. What do they do to their little piggies out here??? 

When the food arrived it was so much and overwhelming we were certain there was no way in hell we could eat it all. But we were wrong, it was soon devoured. She even had to remove her leather jacket to dig in further and cool off her warm, happy belly. 

Kudos to the cooks and the very hip and efficient waitress. But what's with the cash only policy??? It's 2009 buy a credit card machine you crazy hippies! 

Two enthusiastic thumbs up from the two deliciously decadent divas.
author: Drew M.

description:
I have been going to Just for you Cafe about once a month for two years.

Pros

1. Always fresh, especially the fruits
2. Eggs are done CORRECTLY
3. Great Service is the norm
4. Try their home made cornbread
5. Try the beignets!

Cons

1. On the weekends expect to wait
2. Portions seem to be getting smaller over time
3. Can be difficult to find parking on weekends
author: Chi T.

description:
I love Just for You Cafe. This great homey spot is right in my neighborhood and everytime I go in there I feel like i am part of a community.  The lovely staff always smile and say hello. I love to wave to the cooks and check in with the waitresses.  

I am thrilled they have expanded into the night time/dinner realm.  My two favorite waitresses Maria and Katie work at night. I always get the same thing and they know everytime without me having to ask.

Afforable and Awesome...that is all I need! 

Thanks!
author: Jen F.

description:
A tiny place with full of surprises ^_^

-They have a butt load of pictures on the wall (which I love) and random Christmas lights hanging from the kitchen area. 

-I love the beignets! Now it makes me wonder how awesome the New Orlean's beignets are...

-Great service! Our lady server gave my friends and I  free beignets because she felt that our order took too long. (I didn't even have to ask!) 

 I'm gonna go there again. 


NOM NOM NOM CERTIFIED!
author: Jennifer H.

description: this place is really good they have lots of delicious items on the menu including things that are made with good ingredients and made with care by people who have never even been to jail.
author: Flower B.

description:
While up in the city for the day, we stopped here for brunch before heading over to the Park. Now I'm not generally a fan of breakfast/brunch--I'd be fine with a latte for breakfast--but I was pleasantly surprised by my brunch here. 

I ordered one of the scrambles--Greg's, I think?--and it was actually pretty tasty. (And that's saying a lot since I'm not usually a fan of eggs.) The scrambled eggs were mixed with garlic, onions, spinach and chicken-apple sausage. The flavors all blended nicely; my only complaint was the spinach, which wasn't sufficiently cooked or fresh for the dish--it was served in a weird in-between state. Of course we also ordered beignets. These were quite tasty, light and fluffy with nice flavor. Could probably have survived on a single one, but my friend and I split an order (3 per order) because why not?!?!

As expected, there was a wait when we arrived, but despite warnings from fellow Yelpers, it wasn't too bad. Once we were seated, service was pretty fast, which was surprising given a full house on a Saturday morning.

Overall, not bad and I'd definitely go back for those beignets, I'm just not sure when I'll be up in the city again for breakfast/brunch.
author: Raul N.

description:
I've had several meals at this cafe with none of them being anything less than delicious. This is just good, home-cooked style food. 

I recently ordered the patty melt and thoroughly enjoyed it. Loved having the thousand island dressing on the side so I could put as much (or as little) as I wanted on there. I thought the onions could have been fried a little more, but that's a personal preference. The burger patty was cooked to perfection.

Parking in this Dogpatch neighborhood is like trying to win the lottery, but the food and the service at this eatery is worth it.

Great for breakfast and lunches and they now offer dinners on certain nights of the week. Awesome!

If you go, I recommend getting the hot chocolate and, by all means, make sure you order the beignets (deep fried crack).
author: Rory O.

description: Great setting, giant portions. Shared the crab cakes, corn pancakes, and beignets with a friend. All delicious. Wash it down with the unlimited but not very strong coffee. It's a great place to go before or after biking so you can work off the big meal. There's a wait on weekends but things turn over pretty quickly.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Had Greg's Special with Chorizo. It was tasty and filling but nothing to rave over. 

The major plus about this place is it's great for groups compared to other breakfast places and the wait isn't that bad. 

If I'm in the area I might eat here, but nothing to you out of my way for.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
This place is DELICIOUS!  My friends and I went here for brunch Saturday morning.  We shared the French toast, side of house potatoes, and huevos rancheros with "Christmas" sauce (a mixture of their red meat sauce and their green hot sauce).  It's a good thing we shared because the servings are HUGE.  The French toast was delightfully fluffy and full of flavor. The huevos rancheros were filled with tons of food and topped with the delicious sauces.  I preferred the green hot sauce and used it to dip the potatoes in.  Yummo!

Our friends who recommended this place described their cornbread pancakes as "tasting love."  Well, I tasted the "love," and it was actually quite awesome.  It just melts in your mouth and has the wonderful cornbread taste in every bite.  I would definitely come back here again and get my own serving of those pancakes!

The only downfalls 
1)  We were seated in a back corner and the service was slow.  We had to keep going back to the server to ask for refills, utensils, condiments, etc.  
2)  They only take 1 credit card at each table (so no splitting checks...or just bring cash.)
author: Tram T.

description:
Ok, so I decided to give in to my 2-week-long burger craving. I wasn't so sure I should do it here, but I'm so glad that I did! Bacon cheeseburger, a heavenly pure chuck patty topped with cheddar cheese and crispy bacon, served up on a beautiful golden sesame bun. Simple and delicious no frills burger. Side it up with some homemade french fries, you'll be glad you did. Tasty.

G. got the Greg's Scramble with sausage and a side of grits. Grits = good. Yes they are, yes they are. Just needed a little more butter and salt and they were good to go. I'm a grit girl, I should know. G. was thoroughly impressed with his meal. 

We'll be back for more.
author: Carnley P.

description:
I love a place where one can have options of grits, biscuits, cornbread or  potatoes! Yey! 

The 2 eggs with catfish is always a good choice with grits and cornbread! Or try the "cowgirl" special along with their beignets. Yum!
author: Juliet W.

description:
-Update- 

I've returned several times since and am still a fan. I tried the BLT (I wanted some A but they ran out of avocados that morning) and the crab cakes and while Oralia's makes an infinitely better sandwich, what can you expect from a breakfast joint? The crab cakes were pretty good! I think I make them better but that takes some time so for a quick crab cake fix without traveling too far from home, Just For You may just cut it.

-End Update-

I woke up craving buttermilk pancakes. Normally, I'll make 'em myself using my handy-dandy griddle but I didn't have any buttermilk. Who knew there was a great brunch place so close by to where I live?! 

The Boyfriend and I drove over, found a nice parking spot a few feet from the front door and after examining the menu outside, walked in to the register. I ordered a Cowgirl (two pancakes, two eggs any style, two sausage links or two bacon strips) and the Boyfriend wanted a Greg Scramble with chorizo. We also saw on Yelp that a lot of folks liked the beignets so we got some too. 

Yes, our eyes were bigger than our stomachs. I was astonished when a guy came out to us carrying three to-go boxes. The stack was almost up to my knees. The wait for a table wasn't too bad for a Saturday brunch place (I'd say it would have been about 15-30 minutes) and they have a small table set up outside with free coffee. We waited about 10 minutes for our to-go order. 

I was quite pleased with my pancakes. They were big and fluffy and the syrup wasn't any Aunt-Jemima-like-imitation. The sausage and eggs weren't anything to write home about but were passable. The Boyfriend's chorizo scramble was tasty - lots of Parmesan and chorizo and the home fries were nice and mealy. The beignets were what you'd expect - donuty taste and lots of powdered sugar. 

All in all, I'm quite happy with Just For You. As the Boyfriend said, four stars for being solid brunch food. We're planning on going back soon to try other things and maybe they'll wow us into five.
author: Christine P.

description:
I recently started a new job that is a few blocks away on Texas St. Just for you is on of the VERY few choices for places to eat in this area.  I would suggest getting there EARLY for lunch as it's a small place and it fills up fast.

The food is good, no frills, not foo foo and reasonably priced. Certainly not a place to go to if you're on a diet HAHA But definitely worth going to
author: Leo V.

description:
Suspender guy was in winter wear- long pants and no shorts with suspenders

First time ever they got my order wrong and gave me heuvos rancheros with cheese. boooo... still a fan though.
author: Skye W.

description:
Gluten-free bread on the menu!! woohoo!! I might be late to this party though, cause I hadn't been there in while until this weekend.  That deserves a new review though. 

(also, the wheat-free oatmeal pancakes, which have always been there, but are not necessarily gluten-free because of potential griddle contamination, ARE BOMB).
author: sami n.

description:
Being a new patron of the Dogpatch, I have now been to Just for You Cafe twice. I immediately loved the atmosphere, and the signage where they threaten to pour coffee on your cell phone. Any place promoting face to face conversation is an A+ in my book. They display an awesome collection of screen printed concert posters and the atmosphere is laid back but attentive. As another reviewer put it there is really nothing pretentious about it, which is refreshing coming from the Mission.

They are one of the original purveyors of the slow food movement and their menu is New Orleans themed. Its good to know that I have a place where I can get beignets, po boys, and muffaletta sandwiches whenever I want. There is a good selection of vegetarian items, but you can also order a delicious reuben and surprisingly not walk out feeling like you have a brick in your stomach. The quality and freshness of ingredients is apparent throughout. Love this place and will certainly be back.
author: Corinne R.

description:
Mediocrity with a hefty price tag.

Breakfast for 2 

Mine:
Poached eggs : over cooked, solid yolks - should at least be able to cook the basics right? Even I can poach an egg!
Homemade cinnamon raison bread : super dry and dense
Home-fries : remarkably unremarkable

His: 
Scramble, home-fries, english muffin

2 coffees + 2 orange juices

Totaling over 

$50 dollars. (with tip)

Oodles of other restaurants come to mind where we could get an AMAZING breakfast for under $50. Why would you ever come here to eat overpriced, boring, poorly cooked food when there's so many better alternatives in SF?
author: H.S. G.

description:
I give this NEGATIVE stars now that I got a crappy message from the owner...hey fix your crappy food don't argue with our opinions...


Oh now one of the ignorant patrons told me I was a F$#$% Jack@$$...wow now I know what type of trash eats trash
author: Chick M.

description:
Just For You Café puts up a clever front of being a hipster hangout - but I'm here to tell you it's not.  Really.  It's this wonderfully comfortable, casual and delicious little eatery full of snarky signs, and if it were any closer to my home I would be approximately the size of Wisconsin within about, oh, a month.  It's as if they took the traditional diner options, added some high-end foodie touches, spiced it all with a southern flair and created a menu that causes actual angst because you have to pick just ONE dish.  And the coffee - my true decider for any breakfast place - is strong and plentiful.

I am so glad it's a long bus ride away.  That's all I can say.
author: Suzanne B.

description: Pretty disappointed with my experience here given the great reviews.  We waited about a half hour to get our table (pretty standard), but service went downhill from there.  To our server's credit, he was quick to take our order and bring our food, but he only brought 1 water for 2 people and I had to ask for a straw several times before he brought it.  When we got our food, both our orders were wrong and our waiter had to take them back.  Our orders came out again very quickly, but almost too quickly because my eggs were very undercooked.  I have never returned a dish twice and felt strange about it, so I ate it as is, but was very underwhelmed overall.  We did have the beignets, which were very good.  Perhaps it was just a one-off bad experience, but I don't think I will be going back to try it again.
author: Shirley B.

description: Everyone loves it, nobody likes the line.
author: David S.

description:
I love my share of greasy spoons but this place was by far the WORST breakfast I've ever had from east to west coast.  Went for a long run Sunday morning and was famished but still was unable to stomach the food.  We sat in the back near the kitchen and the malodorous wafts of air from within was stomach turning.  Orange juice tasted like dishwater. Chicken sausages were dripping with grease. Oversized cake slice of scone was dry and unpalatable. Home fries were mushy and not crisp. 

There are too many places better and more economical. Don't waste your time.
author: Grace C.

description:
Beignets! They are so good! How good? We are talking Barack Obama at the 2004 DNC convention good--they leave with you the same feeling of possibility and bliss. And they wont let you down like BO has. 

Make sure you ask your waiter for jam. Beignets and jam. Just saying those words brighten my afternoon. 

The food is great too but lets face it--you only eat the food so you can put your food aside to make room for the beignets. 

Now if we could only get our politicians to be as fulfilling as these beignets.
author: George J.

description:
I used to go to park chow for breakfast, but now its "Just for you cafe". Beignets like everyone else says is a must. Go ahead and order them right when you sit down so you can munch on them while you are deciding what to eat. Oh, and get the pint of mimosa. Its not all you can drink like some other places, but, dang a pint is enough for a sunday morning. I gotta work on Monday. 

So far everything Ive had on the menu has been great and brings me back. Ive been trying the specials. I see people getting breakfast burritos and stuff. iono...

Be prepared for a wait on the weekends. Its not a big place, but there is free coffee while you wait.
author: Roy L.

description:
I really like this cafe. The service is friendly, the food is tasty and the menu is great. i've been here several times in the past few months and have never been disappointed with the food or service. 

The burgers are good, the breakfast foods are good, and I can't think of a single complaint. The signs are funny too!
author: Mary M.

description: Took Yelp for a spin, and decided to try this place. The scramble with chicken apple sausage was delicious! The eggs were perfectly cooked, softly scrambled with spinach, onions and garlic, topped with Parmesan, and served with homemade wheat toast! With friendly waitstaff and a gitchy-fun atmosphere, who could ask for more on a Thursday morning?
author: Doris P.

description:
Had the beignet and crab cake with two eggs. A-ok!  I want to come back and try their corned beef hash.

If you come for weekend brunch, be prepared to wait an hour for a table.
author: C L.

description: Yum yum. Just For You totally rules!  Especially the corn bread!
author: chloe w.

description:
I was fooled by the gritty exterior.  It is actually bright, clean and comfy with the most comfortable diner bar stools these cheeks have ever sunk into.  They have a good natured attitude: bathroom sign reads "We're not asking you to be Michael Jordan, just to put your trash in the basket"; at the bar "we reserve the right to pour coffee ... on your cell phone."; outside "we love your baby, not your stroller", etc. 

Pint size mimosas!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Gluten free bread!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

The food is so tasty, fresh and creative and delivered to you by truly hip, laid back individuals.  Great place to meet locals and ole' dogpatch timers. Medium/Large size portions.

Try the crab cake and the beignets.
author: Addrianna R.

description:
While planning an overnight trip to SF, I was looking for a decent breakfast place to eat at in the morning. I'm gluten-free, and had a definite hankering for pancakes - two things that don't mix well, even in big cities like San Francisco. However, with the help of Yelp, I was able to find the Just For You Cafe, and their delicious wheat-free pancakes! These worked for me because I have a wheat specific allergy, but if you are completely gluten intolerant, Just For You has really great egg dishes. My compatriot had the "Greg's Scramble" with chorizo, and he said it was delicious (and I agreed that it looked pretty good!).

Between the two of us, our bill came out to about $20, which was great while on a travel budget. I know I'll be coming back here next time I'm in SF!
author: Kirsten T.

description:
Love this place! The beignets are delicious! The come covered in powdered sugar and I always enjoy them with the jam and honey they have on the table, yummy!

I've tried the Eggs Blackstone and the Greg's Scramble with chicken apple sausage. Eggs Blackstone was good, big portions, although my poached eggs were overcooked :( Not a huge fan of the home fries (potatoes) or the biscuits (dry and crumbly), but the food is solid. The scramble had onions, garlic, spinach, parmesan and sausage... it was fantastic! And their grits are delish - but its pretty hard to mess up grits. I'll be back for sure!

They also have mimosas, large ones at that. Had one my first visit... not memorable, but a mimosa isnt really supposed to be, is it?? :)
author: Aryn Y.

description:
Okay.  I'll admit it.  When I first moved to the DP I was slightly annoyed by the constant congregating taking place outside this establishment.  I went in a few times for breakfast and the food was tasty.  

It wasn't until recently that I became a devout fan of this charming little spot.  

Their reuben sandwich is absolutely to die for.  I'm an east coast girl that knows her Jewish deli delights...however...Carnegie has nothing over Just For You when it comes to the reuben!

Lelakek Et Ha'etzba'ot!
author: Renee F.

description:
we biked all the way from upper haight to this place to try their brunch. It was the week before Christmas and it was a fairwell thing for for my roommates, we were circling around all their favorite places before they left San Fran.
I loved the place. it is pretty small and the line big but they really move people around fast. They had coffee outside for those waiting and random seating spots.
