So our collective curiosity satisfied, we'll keep away, especially as there are so many very good breakfast/brunch places in the area
author: Rounscival H.

description:
I love it here.  I just wish I wasn't that tired to be writing the review.  Labour day.  Monday.  Not hungover.. But exhausted.  Bacon Cheeseburger with home fries and that awesome mustard they have.  My burger did explode all over my hands and beard.  Which is now gone.  The beard that is.  There just was so much in the burger.  IS this making any sense.  Water, no beer.  And then back to work.  What on Labour day?  Yes....  Service is always quick and the decor is hip.  IS the word "hip"  in?....?
Nick
www.lostcampersusa.com
author: Nick T.

description:
not really one of my favorite brunch spots...

i ordered an egg scramble with chicken sausage and it was topped with Parmesan cheese (that part was gross)...it was bland but i think the parm cheese made the dish that much worse

but i do highly recommend the beignets. it was my first time having it and if i go back that is something i would definitely order
author: Annie L.

description:
This is my favorite breakfast place when I am anywhere near Potrero or the ballpark at the right time.  It's great.

Here's your tip of the day--as soon as you sit down (or maybe while you are walking towards your seat) order beignets to go with your coffee.  You don't want to wait for these fried, hot, tasty, and covered with powdered sugar pastries!   Now with your beignets and coffee you can carefully review the menu and specials and maybe end up with crunchy cornmeal pancakes with fresh eggs and a nice chicken apple sausage, or maybe huevos rancheros in a very very tasty sauce...oh, and spring for the real maple syrup!!!
author: Kirk F.

description: Service sucks... if you like being talked down to then go here but if you can let it go then the food is pretty good and the Beignets are to DIE FOR!
author: Sheree A.

description: tons of GF options and you can call ahead!
author: Min M.

description:
We went around 2 pm for a late breakfast.  We hadn't gone before because the line looked daunting.  This time we got on and in relatively quickly.  
Highlights:
- the number of condiments on the table!  I'd say there were in the arena of 15 accoutrement's to add to your dishes.
-the menu.  the menu is witty and clever and you can get just about whatever you want for your breakfast/lunch.
-the ambiance: this place feels local and oozes with personality.

one star off because the service wasn't consistently stellar.
author: Lauren S.

description: The beignets are sure to be the death of me- sort of a cross between Indian fry bread and Krispy Kreme. Don't wear a dark shirt, as the powdered sugar will give the impression for the rest of the day that you STILL haven't kicked your nasty habit. Just two blocks from my new house, I stumbled in on a hungover morning to discover the real reason I moved to this neighborhood. The Benedict was very flavorful, but I wish they hadn't used toast. The pancakes were amazing, though, and the eggs, spuds, and oatmeal all best of the best.
author: Stephen H.

description:
Best breakfast in San Francisco.
What a bold statement but there it is - I've searched high and low for the best breakfast in the city and this place turned out to be the winner.  I usually order the Eggs Blackstone, a great hangover cure: AWESOME bacon (not the Fisher Price crap bacon served at other places), 2 poached eggs and tomato on toast with hollandaise sauce.  Their Hangtown Fry didn't work as advertised, I still had a hangover after but left with a full stomach (it was great).  The beignets are always a treat - be careful not to accidentally inhale the sugar powder topping.  You almost can't go wrong at this place there's so much good food here.
Expect a lineup to get in.  While waiting you can always check out the Hell's Angel's club house nearby ...
author: Ed P.

description:
I liked the atmosphere of this place a lot. I also like the DIY get on the waiting list, and then grab a cup of coffee routine of going to this place.

I walk by Just For You on nearly a daily basis, always wishing I were inside eating those delicious bits o' fried dough.
author: Mike S.

description:
Yummy yummy.

Been here three times now. All three times, my food was delicious, the service was friendly and quick, the atmosphere was cozy and charming, the place was clean.... and really... I can't think of anything to complain about.

Let's see... what have I eaten there?

Asparagus sandwich -- ohmigod, how cool is that? HUGE pieces of perfectly-cooked stalks of asparagus, highlighting this very interesting and delicious sandwich. (Did I mention the homemade bread?) I give them extra points for the creativity factor here.

Fabulous breakfast... eggs nicely done, and that wonderful homemade bread toast...

I had the soup of the day once... I think it was creamy asparagus. (I apparently have a "thing" for asparagus.) The soup was delicious. And came with wonderful homemade bread.

Yes... I also have a "thing" for homemade bread.

And the beignets were terrific! Crisply fried, soft and warm inside, dusted with powdered sugar... just delicious.

There are a few tables out front on the sidewalk, but I've eaten indoors when I've gone there -- and they keep the door wide open, so it's got nice circulating air. 

Nope -- can't think of a thing to complain about. Parking isn't ideal... I've had to walk a few blocks to get there... but you know -- it's worth it. I've never had to wait for a table once I got there.

Five stars!!!
author: Zoe H.

description:
I'm so a fan of this place! Dog patch is an area I hardly ever venture off to. So it was nice to check out a new place. I was craving HIng Lung in Chinatown, but they were closed and I couldn't read the chinese note posted on the door. Oh well... So my friend Matt suggested another place in the Dog Patch. As a SF native I'm very ashamed that I didn't know of this place. But then again, how often do you get to eat break/brunch on a weekday if you have a 9-5 job, right?? 

I have a biscuit gravy with chicken apple sausage, a cup of joe and a bowl of grits... boy was that a complete meal or what? 

My friend had the scamble and it was delicious.. can't go wrong. I hear their french donuts are amazing too. 
Have fun if you're looking for a spot to eat breakfast or brunch. 
If you head over during the weekend you might have to wait.
author: Judi K.

description: I don't really know what can be said that hasn't been said already.  Other than, I think they serve the best, most authentic beignets I've ever had outside of Cafe du Monde in the Quarter in NOLA.  I'm a Mississippi man, so I know southern food.  They handle it.  And for those of you who say you don't like grits because they are flavorless??? Of course they are, until you put in some salt, pepper, a couple pats of butter, some hot sauce and I say go big and crumble up your bacon in it too.  I've had people literally stare at me as I go through my grit preparation ritual.  It's A M A Z I N G!!   Best to arrive prior to 10am tho to minimize the wait.
author: Shawn D.

description:
Just a note- If you happen to be sitting in one of the backless seats at the counter, please make sure you wear underwear. The people sitting at the tables want to enjoy their food without imagining their beignets tasting like your skid-marked jeans. Thank you.

Speaking of beignets, I had to try them since everyone's been raving about them. I was shocked to see how massive they were. They put so much powdered sugar on them that it looked like they're rolling around in a swarm of cocaine. We dumped a whole bunch off the beignets and made about 10 lines with powdered sugar for fun. Wishful thinking I guess. I had the Crabby Bennie which was a sight for hungry eyes. The portion was enormous but I was starving and ate the whole thing, even though it was just alright tasting. However, the OJ was the bomb.

Our waitress was kind of a debbie downer. No smile and it seemed like she didn't want to be there. She got irritated one time and said, "Cell phones aren't allowed in here." Sorry homegirl, we didn't know. But the annoying chick next to us was on her phone BEFORE we even got there and didn't hang up until 15 mins before we left but our waitress didn't say anything to her. Hmph. 

They are cash or check only. There is an ATM at the liquor store next door but the machine charges a $2.25 fee. The place is full of hipsters with staring problems and older folks who love to eat and eat.

On the plus side parking was easy, no wait for tables, and everything was huge and came fast. "That's what she said." Sorry, had to say it! :)
author: Jen Y.

description: This joint rocks!!  Good way to start my weekend with Frittata that has cherry tomatoes, asparagus and pesto!! YUM!! Also the cornbread rocks!! They do such a good job with the cornbread (moist and savory) that I have to take it home to have it for a snack!!  Beignets are a must!!  My tummy is most happy!
author: David C.

description:
we were determined to start the year off with a bang so we wanted to go somewhere we haven't been to on new years morning.  we were thinking of going to sausalito and finding a little breakfast spot but yelp came to the rescue once again and suggested just for you cafe which happened to be open on new years morning.

we got lucky with parking as someone was leaving as soon as we got there but we could see the crowd from a block away.  luckily my cousins got there ahead of us so they were able to sign us up for a spot.  we waited about an hour but we were prepared to wait after reading all the great yelp reviews about this place.  and it totally didn't dissappoint!!

i got an order of beignets - they were the real deal holyfield beignets.  light, fluffy, and dusted with powdered sugar.  scrumptious!

i also got the hangtown fry which if you've never had it, it's the ultimate breakfast and some.  eggs, spinach, bacon, onions all rolled into one and get this not 1, not 2, but 3 deep fried oysters mixed in as well.  served with home potatoes.  i've had this dish at other places, but they pale in comparison to Just For You Cafe's version.

I had a little of my cohorts' breakfastsesss and they were all good.  can't wait to come back here!
author: Ray R.

description:
Just for You Cafe is a really great "local's place".  Newcomers are welcome of course. :)  The only thing on the menu I'm not a fan of are the omlettes.  It's like an egg blanket with steamed insides (you know.. when they use too much egg? )  So -1 star for that.  Everything else that I've had has been yummy.  The scrambles, breakfast burritos and the home made salsas are really special.  The beignets are a terrific way to start off breakfast with just one or three to share with friends.  

The place gets busy past about 11am so expect a wait, but it usually goes pretty fast (they're FAST with their orders).  Coffee is decent and the home made breads (they're all home made I think except for the muffins and bagels) are thick and yummy.  Try the raisin bread, I recommend it.  Sometimes service can slow down a bit when they get busy, but hey... it's a local's place.. and it's inexpensive.  But bring cash, they don't take cards.  oh and the mimosa's are served in big cups.. god bless.. :-)
author: Erik J.

description:
I really like Just For You, and it has a lot to do with Beignets. 

We've been here a few times, and have started to bring friends when we go just to share the love. 

The food is just like from the home kitchen, and the service is friendly and unassuming. Just like the Dogpatch to have a nice place like this. 

While it goes without saying I'm a big fan of the beignets (if you don't know, all the more reason to go), I go to have a normal breakfast/brunch in a place that reminds me that quiet corners of the city still exist. 

I recommend Just For You for your visiting (out of town) friends, for relatives, for brunches with old college/HS buddies, and for regular treat-yourself breakfast outings. 

Five stars because it's perfect for an all-around brekky joint with good food and good character.
author: Razoo D.

description:
3.75 stars

So with 210 reviews, Just For You really isn't an unknown spot.  However,  traveling to the Dogpatch, you wonder who would make the trip out here.  A beignet craving was my reason to jump out of bed early and travel out of my 'hood.

The beignets arrived amply dusted with powdered sugar and were delicious when hot.  They were crunchy and chewy but had a tartness to them which was a bit strange, still good though.

Squid ordered the chili over scrambled eggs atop homemade cornbread...perfect for a hangover.  I had the eggs and flat, rectangular crabcake which was Old Bay-all-the-way tasty.  I think that they should up the crab content and lessen the breadcrumbs since it left me craving for more crab.   

The service that day was attentive and fast.  Thank goodness that we motivated early bc at 9:30 the Brunchers started forming outside.  Overall, I liked Just For You.  Wish that it were closer to home but it's more special just where it is.
author: michelle s.

description: This is my go to place for breakfast and lunch on a day when I need to be in touch with my Southern Roots.  The people are always cool, the owner is generous, and the cooks are stellar.  Hands down best bay area snack.
author: Liz B.

description:
I was pleased to learn this wasn't one of those "cool on the outside, not tasty on the inside" place. First, they knew I was shy when requesting a pre-seated coffee cup outside, and tailored their sign accordingly, almost insisting I ask for a paper cup. We ordered the pillow-sized beignets and I had the pile of homefries with veggies and eggs. When I ordered the homefry dish, I was worried that it was going to be a giant pile of potatoes with weird stale veggies on the side, but I was served a pleasing minimum amount of potatoes to the ratio of fresh stir-fry that was placed on top. I was full, but not in a terrible "I just ate a lot of potatoes" kind of way. And the melted cheese really glued everything together tastefully.

One "complaint" would have to be insane amount of powdered sugar on the beignets.
author: Ross G.

description:
Had brunch after a 20 minute wait in the blazing SF May heat.  In fact it was one of the hotter days in SF.  Since we were eating so late, I toned it down and split a cajun omelet and salad.  Oh, did I mentioned the beignets?  We were supposed to be at Jazz Fest but a plane mishap left here instead.  So this was our Cafe Du Monde proxy.  It was a plate of 3 for $4 and I wanted one and a half.  The other couple said they wanted one but fortunately they didn't care for it so I got 1.70 beignets.  Pretty good at first but later it tasted a bit burnt, which I didn't know was possible.

Anyways the salad was good with a zingly dressing.  But the omelet just wasn't that inspired.  All the right ingredients but so so.  Fortunately the bread came to the rescue.  The bread?  Yes!
Captain HomeMade White Bread!  It had a hearty texture and a wonderful sweet wheat flavor.  The best white bread I can recall having.  

Service was friendly but a bit ad hoc.  You just had to flag them down.
author: Russell Q.

description:
It must be a sign that I *had* to come here today!  It MUST be!!!

So I'm driving down 280 from San Francisco and I ran into rush hour traffic.  I got off at Mariposa just so I can take a quickie shortcut down 3rd St. to get to the next exit @ Cesar Chavez.  (Yeah, THAT crowded!!!)  As I was driving down, I remember a soul food restaurant and remember it being near 22nd St.  So at 22nd St. I made a right turn and started looking around.  The Beignet sign at "Just For You" cafe flashed before me and I thought this was the soul good place.  (This is Sign #1!  And It wasn't the soul food place I was looking for -- that place was just past 22nd St. on 3rd St.  That said...)  I never tried a beignet before but I had heard all the drooling stories from Yelp reviews (I don't know if it's this place or another place...) 5 minutes later, I found parking right across the street from this place!!!  (Sign #2!)

When I was sitting at my table, I had mentioned that I was told I had to try a beignet.  The waitress asked "Do you want one or 3?"  I realize now that I probably SHOULD have asked how big those things are instead of just ordering 3!  Those beignets are HUGE!!!  It's the size of a POP TART... maybe even slightly bigger?  And topped with TONS of snowy powdered sugar goodness in which most ended up on the pair of skating pants I was wearing.  (Not to worry!  It was going straight to the laundry afterwards...)

I also came at Happy Hour... and for $2, I got myself 2 "crispy tacos".   It looked like tacquitos but crispy shell and topped with good homemade salsa!!!  YUM YUM!!!

Next time I want to break my diet though, I'm headin' for the Hangtown Fry!!!  ;)
author: Joanna R.

description:
I went to Just For You last week for the first time and it was delicious.  Weekday morning at 9:00 seems the perfect time to go - not empty, but no wait either.  My basic breakfast of scrambled eggs, grits & toast was very great, and the beignets satisfied my sweet tooth for the whole day!

Even though this place is a diner, it's very clean and the food is fresh and good - no greasy spoon here.  However, it's still a diner offering plain coffee, whole milk, and real eggs (yolk and all).  So don't think about ordering a latte (like my husband did) or egg whites only.
author: brittany z.

description:
This place tucked away in the Dogpatch is A-OK with me.  I like the fact that they are quick and get people in-and-out without too much fanfare.  I won't wait in line for brunch at most places, but I would be willing to wait (a little) here.

They make consistently good omelettes in particular, and I can order them off the menu without having to ask them to add or subtract ingredients from them.  

The only caveat is that the place is a bit cramped, and seating can be tight when they are slammed.  

Portion size is generous, and you can tell the ingredients are fresh.  Prices are fair, and they are efficient.  Why wait in line at Brenda's like a lemming when you can come here?
author: Dave N.

description: Their beignets made it on my top nine tastes of the year list. These suckers come to the table piping hot and huge. HUGE. My boyfriend and I ordered 2 plates of beignets (3 for $4.50) and home fries (avoid) and only made it through half the beignets. They are covered in powdered sugar, are much bigger than the New Orleans version -- almost to the point that you wonder if there's a filling, and you'll feel kind of sick that you ate so many doughnuts, but west of Caf du Monde, it's the best you'll find.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
***4.5 stars, rounded down.***

If you've been reading my reviews, you already know that I love breakfast food and I love Southern food.  Now, imagine there were a place that served Southern breakfast food!  Why, I say, I'd eat there every day!

Just For You is that kind of place.  Located in the Dogpatch district of San Francisco, steps away from Hard Knox Cafe, Just For You is a Southern diner with a San Francisco flair.  Decorations on the walls say it all: 2007 LSU Championship banner and a giant plastic marlin share the space with cool old movie posters and street festival announcements.  Does anyone else think that it's deliciously appropriate that Just For You is located on 22nd Street between Third Street and *Tennessee* St?  

"Wish that I was on ol' rocky top,
Down in the Tennessee hills.
Ain't no smoggy smoke on rocky top,
Ain't no telephone bills."

But I digress.

It's the kind of a place where you show up before 9 am or wait in line for 30 min to an hour.  (while you wait outside, you can help yourself to some coffee, but it hardly helps).  It's the kind of a place where an older couple at the table next to you will strike a conversation with you and your dining companion.  It's the kind of place where the signs on the door say "we love your baby, not your stroller" and "we reserve the right to pour coffee on your cell phone."  I am not even kidding.

My friend and I ordered beignets as an appetizer, 3 for $4.  They were just like the beignets I had in New Orleans, but slightly chewier and covered with way more powdered sugar.  What a delicious way to start your meal!  Then I ordered two scrambled eggs with a ham steak, cornbread and grits.  The scrambled eggs were fine, and the ham steak was a bit overcooked and a bit too salty.  The cornbread was very fresh and still warm, although it was a bit too salty as well.  We also shared the buttermilk pancakes, which had a fluffy, yet doughy texture.

But none of that mattered much.  What I was looking forward to were the grits.  I LOVE grits.  Allow me to quote Just For You menu here: "What's Grits?  It's that pasty white stuff . . . like you had in prison."  Just For You grits were a bit bland for my taste, but with the right amount of salt and pepper, and, perhaps, even butter, I was able to perfect the chef's creation.

It's no Waffle House--nothing is--but Just For You is as close to a great Southern diner as it gets.  I struggled with the rating, because this place is a true 4.5-star establishment.  Yep, it's a bit more than "Yay!  I am a fan," but it's not quite "Woo-hoo!  As good as it gets."  

I can't wait to come back here for breakfast.  Parking is relatively easy to find, and the service is pretty friendly.
author: Yan G.

description: The grits here suck.  The beignet is pretty good.  Portions here are small.  The pancakes were ok.  The cornmeal pancake is a flat piece of conrbread.  Te oatmeal pancake was good but not great. The biscuits were really good here.  Next time I want to try the green chili sauce over a burrito.
author: Fatty A.

description:
I love this place!! We went here for Breakfast on Saturday morning. We were 4 and 1/2 people and waited about 5 minutes! I guess we were lucky. 
I ordered the veggie Omelet and got grits as a side!!! Where can you get grits these days??? Anyway it was really good. The omelet came with salsa, asparagus, onions and some other veggies. The Grits were tummy warming and the service was great even though it was super busy. 
I wish I could go here for breakfast at least 3 times a week! Did I mention that I loved it!!!!!!!!!!
author: Maurice A.

description:
I live right by this place, but I don't go often (after trying it out many times). The beignets are good, but really, how can anything fried and dusted with sugar be icky-tasting? I'm not a fan of their crabcakes or the egg scramble. The french toast is alright, as are the pancakes... sometimes they'll have a decent special, but for a really dependably tasty brunch, I'd say go elsewhere...

OK, I had to update this to 3 stars because the mimosas are served in a PINT GLASS, for the same price as a teeny tiny one you'd get anywhere else.
author: Jacqui M.

description:
One of my favorite breakfast places in San Francisco.

JFY has a great vibe and good breakfast dishes you won't find many places in San Francisco.  The Dogpatch location is a little remote for most people in SF but it's worth the trip.


Not for the Marina or Cow Hollow types as the crowd can be eclectic.
author: Zk K.

description:
I came here on Memorial Day thinking that I could order the Crab Cake Po-Boy because it was a Monday.  I was disappointed to discover that because it was a holiday the only menu being offered was the weekend brunch menu (which does NOT include the Po-Boy).  So, my alternate choice was the Crabby Bennie....it's a Creole crab cake on poached egg over toast with hollandaise sauce.  I was given two choices...English muffin or their homemade bread which was pretty much a sourdough bread.  I'm a fan of sourdough so I couldn't pass up that option.   My dish also came with home fries.  I love a really good biscuit too so I ordered a side of that.

My mom ordered the special frittata (which was basically a vegetable omelette with some cheese) with grits and cornbread.

We also ordered beignets which the cafe describes as "Fresh, Fluffy Pillows of Perfection."

The beignets were soooo good, that my mom wanted to order more for later.  They look like mini pillows dusted with powdered sugar.  The taste reminded me of funnel cake that I used to get as a kid at amusement parks.  

My Crabby Bennie was drenched in hollandaise sauce.  I should have requested the sauce on the side.  My dish was just so-so.  Super heavy because of the sauce, the thick slices of homemade bread, and the huge amount of home fries.  I couldn't finish my plate.  I only took one bite of the side of biscuits I got.  One bite was enough because it was really dry.

I took a bite out of my mom's cornbread.  It was meh.  The cornbread at Momo's is by far the best I've had here in SF...so I end up using my cornbread experience at Momo's as my benchmark.

My friend ordered the catfish filet.  I didn't taste that dish because I just felt it was a little too early in the morning to eat heavily breaded fish.

Service wasn't great...quite slow.  Yes, they were busy but there were a few people to wait on the customers. I would give them 3 stars for service.  The additional star is for their really taste beignets.  We were too full from our meals that my mom didn't bother order an additional serving of beignets to take home.  By the end of the meal, all of us didn't want to see any more food.  It was time for a nap.
author: Michelle N.

description:
Just For You is now open for DINNER on Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday from 4-9pm. 

Dinner was so good that I wanted to go back as soon as we'd walked out the door. Yummy.

I wasn't entirely sure what to expect for a dinner menu from them but they've got a little bit of everything. You can even still get most of the breakfast items! Sandwiches, Po' Boys, Chicken Fried Steak, Fried Calamari, Soup, Chili, Salads, Wine, Mac and Cheese - a huge mix.

I had the Chili Scramble and Grilled Cheese. Both were delicious! I love their homemade bread, soooooooo good. Hubby had the Chicken Fried Steak and said it was good but he could feel his arteries hardening (What do you expect? It's southern cooking and that's how chicken fried steak is supposed to be.) 

The place looks entirely different at night and without the busy weekend brunch crowd. They've dressed it up with little white christmas lights in the front windows and tea lights on the tables. Very cute, cozy, and a prefect spot for a lazy dinner with someone special.

And after our meal they gave us a coupon for 25% off our next visit. *squee!*
author: Audrey N.

description:
Cozy brunch spot with the best bar stools in the world.  I would have given them five stars if there were bar hooks for purses, but alas I had to drop my bag on the floor. Service is quick, there's lots of add-on options for breakfast plates and they serve the biggest beignets and mimosas that I've ever seen.  
It's cash only, parking is easy but there's almost always a wait.  A nice  neighborhood spot if you're in the area.
author: Kimmie N.

description: This place has the best beignets on the planet! Bar none! Go in late night for piping hot beignets and there's no wait like in the mornings!
author: Chrys K.

description:
I can feel the Dogpatch locals leering at me now...I'm sorry guys, but there is no way you're keeping this place a secret!!!  So far, this is my favorite brunch place in San Francisco. Apparently this place is a creole restaurant and you can totally see that peek through in their brunch fair. The best thing I've had there is the Bleu Scramble. I promise you won't be disappointed. 

Also, you MUST get the beignets!!! They are warm, doughy, and covered in powdered sugar. You can even put a little extra syrup on them. It's awesome because it rolls right off of the powdered sugar like little worms :) 

Plus, they have a coffee dispenser outside to keep all the waiting hungry people at bay....Yum!!!!!!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Yum!

I love this place, a friend took me here to nurse my hangover before heading to the indiemart. It was so cute and delicious, no wait at all. I had the Eggs benedict with the crab cakes. I thought their hollandaise was the best I have ever tasted in the city. The potatoes were soft yet crispy with just the right amount of seasoning. I would absolutely come here again, even if it means climbing 2 hills to get there.
author: Javier B.

description:
If I could give it three-and-a-half stars, I would.  Living right around the corner, I've been there enough times to be able to give it a pretty fair review.

The food is great.  The service is mixed.  Since I live nearby I'll wander in at random hours and if things are slow, it's wonderful.  They are on top of everything and you don't feel rushed and it's a really wonderful experience.

However, if you try to go on the weekends when they get ultra-busy, service suffers terribly.  It isn't that they aren't friendly, but they are completely hurried and seem to be understaffed.  I'd see my food sitting up and waiting to be delivered for sooo long that you just want to go get it yourself.  

When your food does come, the tempo feels like you just need to pound it and get the heck out of there because there are people lined up all over the sidewalk and even the staff can't stop for a moment to get you coffee or water.  If you grab one they will apologize and try to help you, but it seems like they have 100 different things going on, it doesn't look like fun.

So, wander in during a quiet time and the place is magical-good.  Try to avoid the peak periods if possible, as it will significantly lessen an otherwise wonderful experience where you won't be able to appreciate their good food, cute place, and warm staff.
author: Doug M.

description:
No doubt this place is my favorite little breakfast spot in the city.  The eggs are always nice and fluffy, bacon is thick, and the food always seems fresher than many breakfast cafe's I've been to.  The only drawback to this place is you really have to get there early on the weekend as it fills up by about 10am, and the dining area only holds about 30 people at a time most.  Luckily, the service was prompt, so the wait time doesn't seem that bad. 

I'll be back again and again!
author: C R.

description: Love this place.  Get the breakfast burrito with a side of green chili if you like spicy.  The green chilis are flown in from NM as I understand it.  The cinnamon raisin bread is home made and tasty.  And you have to have a beignet!  I would stay away from the coffee, but a pint size mimosa is a nice treat.
author: Keri K.

description: SF was good to me & my belly.  On our way out we stopped by this cafe Monday around 10:30 - 11am with no line.  Located in the Dog Patch area, the place was artsy, small and you felt lucky to have found parking. Known for their beignets and snarky signs - we ordered 3 of them & the standard breakfasts - eggs, scramble & cinnamon raisin toasts. Never having a beignets before, I am a fan. The outside was crisp and moist inside. The powdered sugar on top was literally icing on the cake. I sampled a piece with their syrup and it was just so much better alone.  Very cute vibe, great service & wonderful menu. Definitely worth the visit and the calories.
author: Mimi S.

description:
I've been here several times and it's definitely one of my favorite breakfast spots in SF. The french toast is great and their bacon is simply the best I've had in the Bay Area, I'd almost make the trip across down for a single piece of their bacon.

The only downside to this place is the line that can form on a weekend morning, sometimes I've seen the line last 45 mins since the place itself is quiet small and the word is definitely out that the breakfast is fantastic.

I'll definitely be back.
author: Bryan B.

description:
"Go Bignet or Go Home"

In Ireland where a pint of Guinness is a way of life everyone has their 'local'.  It stands to reason that in San Francisco a person's 'local' is the place they go to have their favorite breakfast.  

My local is Just For You. I'm pretty much there once a week on average, tending to hit it on a weekday to enjoy the slower pace, no waiting list and get some Greg's Eggs in my belly to fuel my work efforts for the day.

The staff is friendly, attentive and there's always a nice cross section of people from the local hood debating politics, talking about the weather or just chowing down on the great breakfast foods with a bit of a southern flair.
author: Derek D.

description:
You have to trek a bit off the beaten path to get to Just For You (Dogpatch), but I'm willing to go the distance for great brunch.  I'm not sure this is worth it.  Wait wasn't terrible (15 minutes) and the menu is extensive, but it's missing some of the basics.  I can live with drip coffee (no espresso machine) but would have liked something other than whole milk.  The menu is full of warnings about stuff they sometimes have, but mostly don't (e.g., "oatmeal, with brown sugar when we have it" or "soy milk - you can ask but you're probably out of luck").  

I ordered the eggs benedict and grits, which was decent. The hollandaise was a little thin, but tasted fine.  My friend ordered a hodge podge of sides which were okay.  Bottom line: nothing special, especially for a place so far out of the way.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
Had a Zipcar for the day so I drove over to Just For You at 8:30 on a Saturday morning and got a table right away (but people were waiting by the time we left at 9:30). This was our first time and the staff was pleasant and attentive (I'm pretty sure we were waited on by the owner who is said to be cranky in other reviews but she was okay) and the food was good. I had Greg's Scramble with bacon since everything's better with bacon. Very tasty  sauteed with onions and spinach. The old man had buckwheat pancakes and sausage. Tasted both, both good. My biscuit was good but not great and the grits would have been better with cheese but that's just me. I'll definitely go back for the beignets.

Update: been back many times since initial review, no complaints, other than I wish it were closer to my neighborhood.
author: Pam D.

description:
aw shucks.

I wasn't really impressed w/ this cafe. I was hoping it'd knock my socks off since I had been meaning to go for quite some time, but it was just average. 

The beignets were warm & tasty and served Cafe du Monde style. However, Brenda's beignets are still #1 in my book. I ordered their Chili Scramble w/ a side of grits w/ the scramble's flavors uninteresting and the grits bland as ever.

Service was as friendly as it gets, so I'm disappointed that their brunch didn't measure up.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Hooray for Mabel's Just For You! And, you know what, it really IS just for you. You. You right there. You're thinking of going for breakfast? Go to Mabel's Just For You. 

The menu is funny, the waitrons are sweet, the line is never terribly long, you can easily find parking, it's conveniently located right by CalTrain for your peninsula pals, and it's right by the T line, 48, and 22 for your Muni riders. 

The food, you ask? Eggs, toast, beignets, coffee, all just hit the spot. 

One time, though, I got the oyster omelette thing, which was guaranteed to cure a hangover, and, well, it really didn't.
author: Melinda K.

description: Very good food and the prices are reasonable. The Beignets are Amazing and a must have in San Francisco. All the dishes I have tried there are very good. Parking is a nightmare and it can be a bit of a wait but, can I hold that against them def. not especially the latter!
author: Mike R.

description:
I took a star away cuz the wait is so long but this place is tiny and people love it so what should I expect?

I have never had a bad meal from here - from eggs and chorizo to a burger. They bake their own bread - get the cornbread, it's awesome. Their coffee is delish. The beignets are always good when I have had them and I used to eat there an embarrassing amount. :) Also, $5 mimosas in a pint glass? Excellent.

The servers bust ass and are nice, too! Parking ain't sooo bad in this hood. And, the liquor store next door is friendly and will give you cash back when you get done eating and realize you spent all your money at the bar last night. I could have sworn I had a $20 left!
author: Neely M.

description:
This place would be a 4-star cafe if it weren't for their dinner service (which I think they started rather recently).

I came here twice, once for brunch and once for dinner. It was like night and day... the brunch is amazing, though there is a long wait, they hustle people in and out pretty fast, plus they have free hot, delicious coffee outside with cream and sugar for waiting patrons. 

I got a chili scramble which was sufficiently savory and tasty, but it did not stand out in any way over other chili scrambles I've had. I also ordered a hot chocolate with soy milk, which was pretty disappointing (read: Nestle instant hot chocolate :(  )

My friend got some sort of omelette, I forget what kind. But we split the beignets, which were 3 for $4. WOW!!!! These beignets were warm, delicious, sweet, fluffy... we couldn't finish the last one so I boxed it up and took it home. And the price? A total bargain!!! I give their brunch 4 stars.

Unfortunately, their dinner service gets 2 stars. The menu is way vast, they need to trim it down. I came with the same friend I went to brunch with and we split clam chowder (which was served tepid and underseasoned), pork chops with veggies (the veggies came straight out of a frozen bag and the pork required a chainsaw to cut apart and chew), and tilapia fish with pico de gallo (basically they drenched a tired old frozen piece of fish with tabasco sauce). The total damage came out to $45. BAAAAADDD.

I would warn you about the dinner service, I think this place has the potential to rise up to the occasion and clean up their act for dinner, since they are able to put out a great brunch service, but they really need to focus on a few simple, delicious dishes they are good at and cut out the dozens of other items they have on the dinner menu that they clearly aren't capable of making. Also there was nobody inside the restaurant when we had dinner, which is an indication of just how bad the dinner service is.
author: ting b.

description: first time here and a great experience thanks to our server M I K E!  he was very helpful with the menu and won us over with his fun attitude. i will come back soon for another glass of his special margaritas!
author: Chrysanthe C.

description:
There's something about the Dogpatch that's so intriguing. My co-workers and I like to trek out there for long Friday lunches, especially when we're in the mood for breakfast. Usually the Frittata of the Decade is divine with lots of veggies and yummy cheese and the perfect amount of moisture, but it wasn't so great today. They were busy-- still, I think food quality shouldn't suffer. But it comes down to this: 

Hit or miss food and service. Fun menu. Laid back atmosphere. 
Makes it worth checking out the Dogpatch before the light rail changes everything.
author: Michie L.

description: We arrived around 9:15am and were able to get a seat right away.  We started off with the beignets which had some powdered sugar sprinkled over it.  It had an interesting chewy consistency and was a somewhat sour dough.  I ordered the Creole crab cake with sides of grits and biscuits.  My friend ordered Greg's scramble.  Both dishes were very yummy though we had a ton of leftovers.  Next time we'll order the beignets then just share a dish.
author: Cindy B.

description:
This place is a favorite for brunch...waiting for a table is the usual routine but worth it because of the beignets...order them just when your seated...they are sprinkled with powdered sugar just the right touch to these warm melt in your mouth  treat with your first gulp of coffee...

Of course I am a fan of their cornmeal cakes, but if I am doing the beignets, I will opt for one of the scrambles... I have to say you can't go wrong with the food...

There are days that the service is great and when they are really busy it can be tough getting served...But I am willing to spend my time their for a good meal.
author: Scooter G.

description: Great place for breakfast!!! Fast, clean and delicious!  Parking available in the nearby streets.
author: Eileen C.

description: Great neighborhood Restraunt. Prices reasonable, lovely owner.
author: Zain E.

description:
In any other city, Just For You would be a serious brunch contender. They've got the style and atmosphere down. But... style and atmosphere are not delicious with a cup of strong coffee.

Neither, it turns out, are Just For You's beignets.

There is just some element of deliciousness missing here.

But listen: It's still good. And a fine choice if you're in the neighborhood. Guzzle some coffee, scarf an omelette. Skip the donuts. Go for a walk.
author: robin s.

description:
I love Just for You. It's a quick 5 minute walk from my SF apartment, so that's an added bonus for me. And for those who have to drive, there's plenty of parking in the Dog Patch!

I passed by JFY for months before checking it out. I'd see crowds of people standing outside the joint while walking my dog in the neighborhood. Finally decided to go for brunch one Saturday morning, and I was pleasantly surprised to find the food yummy with a southern feel to it.

Whether you order their granola with fruit and yogurt or their chili scramble over cornbread, you won't leave with an unsatisfied stomach. An added bonus? They serve fluffy beignets sprinkled with confection sugar hot off the oven!

Tip: On weekends, get there before 11am if you want to avoid waiting for a table for over 15 minutes. If you come later, expect to wait a long, long time. And because seating's pretty limited, I'd recommend just going here for 2some meals, NOT large groups. Also, they don't take credit card so bring CASH.
author: Joyce S.

description:
As one of my favorite brunch/linner spots in SF, I thought Just For You would be the perfect spot to meet up with a group of local and out-of -town friends for breakfast this morning, so we packed a half-ton of ladies into a couple of cars and made our way to Dogpatch.

Now, I'm not complaining about the wait. I knew there would be a wait, especially for a group, and everybody was apprised of this and impressed with the coffee-while-you-wait setup. We actually didn't wait too long, since we compromised the group dynamic by having 3 volunteers sit at the bar while the rest of us took a table. 

I'm also not complaining about the rapid changes to the neighborhood and is demographics, startling as they were. We actually found parking quickly, and the babies were all cute enough. I'm really not even complaining about the service, since the place is packed, although I think my girlfriend really needed more than one cup of coffee after last night, and my friend actually did want that milk and cornbread, even if it was sickening to imagine that she was going to pack it away alongside her Cowgirl breakfast. 

My REALLY BIG PROBLEM is the hollandaise. I ordered the "Special Scramble #1," which is basically 3 eggs, spinach, mushrooms, shrimp, and crab cake bits all scrambled and covered with hollandaise. Yum, right? I know, and I was really looking forward to dipping my home fries in some yolky, buttery, lemon-scented goodness. And then my food came.

Hollandaise sauce is made of egg yolks, butter, and lemon juice. All three of these foods are extremely YELLOW in color, and when emulsified into a sauce should coat a spoon or finger, like thick gravy or melted ice cream. I've eaten hollandaise sauce in many different places and at many different times. Some has been sublime, other sub par, and as long as it's not chunky I can usually cope. But never, ever, EVER have I encountered GRAY HOLLANDAISE SAUCE. Yes, gray. And chunky, like watery ricotta. It was like the discharge of various STDs is often described, actually. It was totally gonorrhea sauce. 

I sent my plate back before it even hit the table. I said, "This is wrong, the sauce is broken." That was a vast understatement of what was the matter, but I figured any cook could look at my plate and instantly know what the problem was. However, when my plate came back it was simply with naked eggs---and A GIANT SIDE OF THE GRAY HOLLANDAISE. It looked exactly like the sides of grits other people were getting. I stuck my finger in the bowl to demonstrate that it was not a proper sauce, and got a finger full of grease and chunks of what appeared to be cooked egg yolks. It tasted and smelled like hard-boiled eggs. Who the fuck would serve that to somebody? Who the fuck would want that on their eggs? I told the runner they needed to make a new batch, and proceeded to eat my unsauced eggs.

A few moments later a server came by, and told me that the kitchen could not make more hollandaise, that this was the batch for the day. OK, I know that this shit sits around, and I accept that fact because I love hollandaise and it usually doesn't make too much of a difference. But what I got should have been thrown out before it ever hit my plate, and I suspect it was never right to begin with. Plus, it only takes about 30 seconds to make, especially in the blender. I told the waitress that if they weren't going to make more sauce they needed to stop serving it to people, and at that point I didn't just mean me, I meant anybody who happened to eat at this restaurant that I've been raving about for 4 years---but then I saw a benedict come out, covered with the ghastly gray stuff.  

It makes me sad to see Just For You go downhill like that. You used to be able to taste the love, and now I detect a hint of absentee ownership and cheap kitchen labor. They've also taken my favorite sandwich, the veggie reuben, off of the menu. The three stars are for the courtesy coffee outside and the unbelievable begniets, which are still worth seeking out once in a while. But beware the hollandaise!
author: Sarah S.

description:
Such a great little find in Dog Patch!  The food is fabulous -- been there twice for breakfast now and twice for lunch and haven't been disappointed yet.  Loved their fish tacos, and their breakfasts completely hit the mark.  I never leave without having had a beignet -- perfect in every way!  If you go, you must have at least one!  

I actually had brunch there today.  It was packed to the rafters and our party was #8 on the waiting list.  Any other place, we would have bolted for something quicker, but it was worth the wait, which really turned out not to be that bad.  Service is quick and always friendly.  

The menu, as well as the restaurant, displays lots of little sarcastic signs like "We reserve the right to pour coffee on your cell phone," which my sense of humor loves, but that sarcasm has never been witnessed in any of the staff.  Always pleasant, smiling, and eager to please.  A+++++++++
author: Theresa J.

description:
Their beignets are to die for! I've tried the beignet flight at Brenda's French Soul food and it is NOT as good compared to Just for You Cafe. Just for You's plain powder sugar beignets beats Brench's chocolate stuffed, crawfish stuff, apple stuffed beignets any day! 

I ate other brunch food there too--its so so. But 5 stars on the beignets for sure!
author: Kim D.

description:
So, this place has been rockin' a solid #2 on my best Bay Area brunch list (actual Yelp list coming soon), but after a particularly awesome experience there a couple weeks ago, it just might be the new #1.

It went like this... after a night of heavy boozing, my companion and I sauntered into Just For You (did they ditch the "Mabel's" part?) and were immediately swept off our feet by the sweet smell of beignets (http://www.justforyoucafe.com/_img/menu/beignets-weekend.gif) coming from the kitchen and the calming sounds of Pinback (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinback) coming from the speakers.  We then promptly threw down the perfect triple beverage order (water, coffee, mimosa) and proceeded to have one the most wonderfully indulgent brunches ever.  I mean, I'm pretty sure we ordered three sides of bacon.

These guys have one of the best brunch menus I've ever seen.  From the hangover scramble (see below) to the grilled catfish, everything is solid, and their specials (homemade corned beef hash!) rock almost as hard as the classic Bottom of the Hill show posters adorning the walls.
author: Kevin D.

description:
What a great little place!
My boyfriend and I were in town for a graduation and our friend brought us here and said it was his favorite breakfast spot in the city.
He wasn't lying!
We came on a Sat morning, it was pretty crowded so we had to wait about 30 min. I love how veg friendly the menu is. I figured I'd be stuck ordering something boring, but I was pleasantly surprised. 
I ordered Greg's Scramble (vegetarian style) and my boyfriend got the Crabby Bennie (a Creole crab cake on toast with hollandaise sauce). I'm usually not a big breakfast person, but it was sooo good! I've yet to find a breakfast place this good in L.A. I had a bite of my friend's buttermilk pancakes and just about fell over in my chair....they were unbelievable. 
Next time I'm visiting SF I'll definitely be back!
author: Shani D.

description:
I love Just For You. 

I love that they have longanisa (Filipino sausage) on their brunch menu.  And it was tasty, too!  I love that their cornbread is sweet but not overly sweet. I love that they have outdoor tables, which are perfect when dining with your pooch.  I love that you can help yourself with coffee outside while waiting for your table.  And I love that it's so close to our loft in the Dogpatch.

We will be back for more.  Like the beignets and the cornmeal pancakes.
author: Jun B.

description: Fantastic place for lunch/brunch. Great food. Nice staff
author: Robert S.

description: Love love love their crabby benny. I have followed JFU for almost 12 years now, starting at the location on Potrero Hill now occupied by Chez Maman. My GF is from Louisiana and she loves Community Coffee, which they serve and sell at Just For You!!
author: Viv A.

description:
I enjoyed the eclectic ambience.  Wait staff was friendly

I did have the beignets -- OMG!!!  I ordered 3 and when I first tried it it looked so overwhelming.. it was huge.  Come to find out, it was just airy, but it was very tasteful.  they tend to overdue it with the powder sugar, but you can always dust it off.

I've only gone during the week for breakfast so I was never faced with waiting in line, but I can totally see how rowded it can get.

Breakfast menu is also great.  You can find a couple in the Guardian newspaper for 1/2 off second breakfast :-)
author: R M.

description: Five stars for the deep friend pastry things sprinkled with powdered sugar.  Minus one star for the long wait and loud service.  Add one star for those deep fried pastry things again....
author: H.A. ..

description:
Excellent beignets...really, really, really yummy.  Save the airfare to New Orleans; you have a Cafe du Monde right here in Dogpatch.  Other than that the food was good and the service was solid.   No complaints.  

Clearly though the owner has lots to complain about.  I felt that Sister Mary Angelica had written all the signs instructing people what to do, what not to do, whether a stroller was OK, whether you could talk on your cell phone, how long you should wash your hands, etc.  OK, I get it.  Its your place and thus its your rules.  But hey, its my money and I'll eat where I feel welcome.
author: G-Rex R.

description: I'm very sad that they shut down dinner here. Hopefully a couple more years of gentrification and there will be enough interest in the area to support a dinner crowd. Thankfully its still possible to get their amazing chicken piccata when they are open.
author: Rocker D.

description: Great brunch place. Good environment: full and lively, but not too loud. The service was also pretty quick. You need to start out by trying the beignets. They are really soft. Next, move on to something savory. There are a lot of good options; my friend and I went with the Greg's scramble with chicken apple sausage (dish was frequently mentioned in Yelp reviews). The portions are fairly generous and pretty inexpensive. I definitely will be going back (today was my first time), but I will likely try a different entree next time.
author: Rami R.

description: One of my favourite place to eat in SF. Simple, cosy, quirky with delicious, delicious food for a great price. The ingredients are carefully sourced from the best suppliers. The guys who run the place are obviously in love with what they do - and you will love the result. The beignets are a must. :)
author: Katalin G.

description: Yum! My first experience with beignets was fantastic, but the eggs and toast that was my "real" breakfast was delicious and fresh too. A nice quiet area of SF where parking is easy too.
author: Anne R.

description:
Excellent place for breakfast in Potrero.  Good ole home cookin - I usually get the scramble, potatoes, and sausage.  It's all good at reasonable prices.  Plus, it's in Potrero - most every time I've been here, it is warm and sunny.

For those that love Beignet's - this is the place to go.
author: Gina C.

description:
come here for dinner. I live in the neighborhood and looove the idea of having a cute, friendly, homey little cafe right around the corner. Morning times, however, can be a bit of a wait for a table and ya, like most breakfast joints in town, you do get rushed a tad. 

When my boyfriend and I went there for dinner, there were four other people in the place. We had two waitresses helping us, chatting with us, totally sweet gals and very helpful. I'm pretty sure they gave me the biggest piece of lasagna I have ever been served, and for two meals it was like 23 bucks or something ridiculously reasonable. No rushage. No poor service. Just happy bellys.
author: Krysti S.

description: Frittata was amazing! Oysters and bacon??? Need I say more?
author: Ahmad W.

description:
The wait??  Mmmm... Longgggg.  However, they make up for it with the free drip coffee outside.

The food??  Deeee-lish!  We started with their famous beignets and smothered them with homemade raspberry jam -- C'est Magnific!!  The grits were grrrrreat, the coffee was fresh, and the breakfast choices are a'plentiful.

This is a great spot for brunch on a cold Sunday [or any cold day that ends in "Y"].  It's a bit out there in Dog Patch-landia, but make the trip [and thank me later].
author: Katie C.

description:
Beignets! BIG ONES!!! DANG THEY ARE GOOD!!!

The staff was nothing short of  rad. Awesome service, and lots of smiles. I can tell they actually like being there ;) This one gal said it was her birthday and she was still there at work! How cute.

I was lucky to be sitting across from my cute man outside of this great cafe on a beautiful sunny day (today).

Good Coffee (I am a cafe junkie, this is a must!!!), Nice fun decor, and THEY HAVE PO'BOYS!! If you don't know what a Po'boy is... Well... I'm sorry.
I got the Huevos Rancheros, it was HUGE and Yummy. A bit too much cheese for me, but a cheese lovers delight.

Anyway, big thumbs up, I am getting an Oyster Po'Boy for sho in the near future!
author: Kellie P.

description: Best breakfast in the city. Food overall beats most if not all eateries in the city. A must stop for anyone visiting the SF. It can get crowded, but it's more than worth the wait. You get tons of food for your money, so you will leave stuffed!!
author: Mr M.

description:
Venturing outside of my neighborhood for brunch is not proving to be worth the gasoline... I was excited to try this place, but it was just ok for me (I am seriously channeling American Idol - "it was just ok for me, dawg"). 

The food was ok, and the beignets were overrated. You can't just fry dough and put some sugar on it and call it a day. I mean, you could, and it would probably taste decent (let's face it), but it's not necessarily a beignet.

Maybe brunch places are really specific to their neighborhoods and therefore they satisfy people who can walk there. But for me, this was another place that wasn't worth getting in the car.
author: Shal J.

description: I had a great brunch here on Sunday. If you're going to be quick I recommend going about a half hour / 45 minutes before they close and you won't have to wait. My friends got some beignets and eggs benedict, and I got biscuits and gravy. Everything was awesome, and reasonably priced. It tasted way better than Boogaloos. Will definitely be back.
author: Beth D.

description:
My fiance works close by and often goes here for breakfast with his co-workers.  He took me here one Saturday morning and it was so ridiculously crowded that we decided not to go.  Instead, I met him for breakfast a week later on Monday (I had the day off), and there were only three other patrons besides us...that's more like it!

The service was quick, and the food was awesome!  I ordered the cowboy breakfast--french toast, eggs and sausage.  Everything was scruptiously tasty.  I would definately go back...but not on the weekend.  I'm not into waiting more than an hour for my breakfast unless I'm making it myself!
author: Krista R.

description:
I miss you Just for you. I know you're just for me b/c you thought to serve mouth-watering  New Mexico green chile for which I will eternally be a fan. I used to belly up to the counter at your old location too and you've never let me down since. Your beignets are simply brilliant and the hangtown fry is tAsty!!
3.5
author: Sandrita R.

description:
This spot reminds me a bit of the NYC-- something about the interior and the street. A diverse crowd of Dotconners and artist-types were already eating (do these people ever work?). 

Upon entering, the wonderful smell of baking yeasty type treats granted me a peak back into my youth-- my dad (a rocket scientist) is an amazing baker; this fact has certainly put a little tonnage upon me (should a 6'3" vegetarian go 220, it is a fit-220), but it has also allowed me to really appreciate the sweet things.

The menu is quite nice as it appears you can order breakfast at anytime, but, being lunch, I ordered a Veggie Reuben and a beignet (I had to, I love beignets). My companion had grilled cheese and a salad which she enjoyed. It looked delicious.

The Reuben was beautiful and almost as hot as our waitress (you know the one :) ). The veggies were wonderfully cooked and the Reuben sauce was perfectly proportioned and seasoned. Really quite nice. The best part was that the rye bread (made in-house) was perfectly toasted-- I love it when the center is crunchy and moist while the crust is crunchy and chewy. Wow!
Great lemonade and appears to be 'endless'.

I was really feeling 5 stars here (8 stars for the waitress)-- I know, I know. Rest assured that I am just looking at the menu and not ordering.

Then I took a bite of beignet. How do I say this without sounding unclear?
The beignets are awful. Almost rancid.
Tasted totally store-bought mix to me. Too salty, consistency not good at all and too much powdered sugar (a thick layer of Gu that actually turned bitter. How is that possible?) and not enough of that deep-fried magic. 

It could have been a bad day for the fry cook it could have been that the oil was either too new or too old, I guess, or is it just that they have no love for the beignets? Just using, abusing perhaps, them as a marketing tool. Dough can be temperamental and insolent if ignored or taken lightly, and when scorned all the sugar in the world will not make it delicious again.

I think out this way you get soppapillas, but if you really, really want a beignet this ain't the place (The Farmer's Market in LA has a nice beignet.)
author: Roop D.

description:
Turkey apple patty = sunday morning heavenly hang over relief

I have only one complaint; the waiting list. People seem to like to get clever with where they write their name and skip you in line. I don't know if that's cuz my complexion is a bit darker than the dogpatch regulars or they think they are slick but I get tired of telling people they are being wrong.
author: Bret S.

description: Regular old breakfast dressed up in brunchy prices is a turn off.  The only real draw here is the beignets, which are great.  Everything else is standard diner breakfast, nothing special about anything here.  Except their prices (ex. sliced avocado is $2.25...uh, freals?)  So not worth it.  They also lost a star for being difficult...they'll only accept one credit card per check.  So if you go with four peeps and everyone has plastic, one person gets stuck with the bill or you're all running for an atm.  I mean, yes, it's annoying to split a check onto four cards, and no, we didn't try to do that, but it irked me they "couldn't" take two cards.  Everyone knows damn well it's *wouldn't* not couldn't.
author: Emily T.

description:
When the menu itself starts sassing you back, you know you entered a good place.  We got seated right away and I couldn't believe the size of their beignets..they were like comfy pillows! I'm glad they offer full plate and single portions to order...I swear I can't eat that much T__T.

I love the Greg's Scramble with chicken apple sausage...I think anything with apples in it is gold!
My cousins got the Frittatas of the Decade and Greg's Scramble with mushrooms.
Can I get a holla from my soul food brutha! The portions were good and the atmosphere was homey.

Getting here was an adventure, why didn't anyone tell me that mapquest is run by a she-demon? Going there from Potrero Hill was hell! We got lost in the park, swarmed all over curvy lanes...I could have just went there by 3rd Street instead!

Parking is non-metered areas for 2 hours...we got lucky and got in right away, but I heard lines are aplenty and only bring cash...mama don't take that plastic crap.
author: Pauline L.

description:
The latest SF breakfast favorite.

Beignet - one of the human's greatest invention.  Plump, deep-fried in vat and sprinkled with powdery sugar, it is the uber sinful treat - consuming it during brunch is almost analogous to getting liquored up at 11AM.

But in this popular little cafe in a little semi-industrial area of San Francisco called Dogpatch, beignet is just a beginning to an even more sinful morning meal: two eggs over easy, Louisiana spicy sausage, two slices of thick homemade toasts, homemade preservative-free strawberry jam and crispy home fries.

The wait can be somewhat ridiculous and the tables are so close together you couldn't help overhearing the patrons, likely to be of the hipster variety, sitting at the next table whispering sweet nothing to one another, but it was definitely well worth it.  

And, really, after spending countless Saturday mornings spending up to 45 minutes waiting for a table at Los Gatos Cafe, this wait is nothing.
author: Ange L.

description:
THIS REVIEW IS FOR PINOY PRIDE

pretty good breakfast, never a horrible wait like dotties, in new honkeytown.

first time i came here i was ultimately annoyed with white people (whom i am disgusted by) and unimpressed by the food compared to how much the white people liked it.

the reasons i was wrong, and just for you is good:

1) longaniza is a sausage choice, theres a filipino back there somewhere, now if i can get some white rice with my breakfast.

2) theres a painting on the wall that says 31337 haxor on it, this makes me laugh endlessly

3) the liquor store nextdoor sells 75 cent tall cans of colt 45 which one can drink while waiting for a table (and therefore keep the old ways of the neigborhood intact)
author: christopher a.

description: A hip spot, but the food was just OK. Nothing to come back for except the beignets.
author: Heiko P.

description:
best salade nicoise in san francisco!
Arienne knows how to serve wholesome
delicious food!
youtube.com/user/justforyoucafe
author: aline d.

description: Like everyone else said it's the beignets.  Get it and enjoy.  The rest of the menu is average.
author: Laurence H.

description: Such a fun, eclectic cafe. The beanie's are amazing with a touch of syrup!! You have to make it out the Dogpatch area and try this little get of a place!
author: lorrin S.

description: Depending on the time that you come in to eat, parking is a hit or miss.. Food is priced extremely fair for the amount and service you get. Super tasty cornbread!
author: Neek W.

description:
Greg's Scramble, oatmeal pancakes, grits and hash.   

The cornmeal pancakes are pretty good too.  

Breakfast comes with a little attitude, but if you're nice, they'll be nice back!  
Definitely one of the best places for breakfast in San Francisco.
author: L. K.

description: It's a cute cozy place with excellent service. They come by frequently to refill your coffee. They have the best beignets! They were light, crispy and smothered in powdered sugar. I laughed at the amount they put on there, but found myself using my beignet as a sponge trying to mop up every last bit of it. I also had the chili scramble. Whoever came up with this is a total genius! Chili on top of scrambled eggs on top of corn bread. *drool*
author: Adelina W.

description:
there's always a wait here but it's well worth it. some favorites are the biscuits with gravy and eggs with longanisa (filipino sausage). i hadn't had longanisa since i was a kid (it was sweet, spicy, and fatty like i remembered) and i was so stoked to find it here that i called my pops to tell him about it. one of these days i'll find out how it got on this menu, of all places...

oh yeah, and you've got to try the beignets if you go. it'll make you feel all warm inside and put an even bigger smile on your face as you leave.
author: Art O.

description: Good place for breakfast in Potrero .
author: Jim J.

description:
What a cute venue! Love the neighborhood and love the layout of the place. 

They've got some great choices on the menu. It's 3 pages and has everything from eggs benedict to huevos rancheros to a garden burger. My heart skipped a beat when I saw grits, biscuits and gravy, LOVE these options for brunch! I had 2 buttermilk pancakes and the biscuits and gravy. The pancakes were ok, nothing spectacular and didn't taste too different from other brunch spots. The biscuits and gravy on the other hand were a hit and I couldn't stop myself from scraping the remnants even though I was full. The coffee was pretty good too. 

I shelled out $16 including tax and tip and left full and happy (and not broke, yaay!).
author: Swetha G.

description:
Just for You is delicious and wonderful. They've got a nice attitude here (they reserve the right to pour coffee on your cell phone, they'll take a personal check but no credit cards, etc.) and the breakfast is great and served all day. 
The Mexican dishes are awesome with the New Mexico green chile sauce. The egg dishes are great too; and they'll give you a bucketload of starches to go with (grits or homefries, plus toast, cornbread, biscuit, or scone). They make most of their baked goods themselves; likewise they roast their own turkey - really like their turkey sandwich!!
author: Teo W.

description:
Not bad by any means, but i was hoping for a lot better. I moved around the corner from this place a few months back and was excited when i read the reviews. Although i continue to go here, i often find myself wishing that it was better. 
+1 convenience
+1 service
+1 consistent

Other than that, nothing has ever wowed me.
author: charlie A.

description: Best restaurant in Dogpatch by far. I love the patty melt for lunch and the various bennedicts for breakfast.
author: Nick K.

description:
I stumbled by this place in the middle of house-hunting and I've got to say that I was so excited to find beignets!  These things were huge, and tasty, but not like cafe du monde.  I would die for those.  I gained 6lbs eating those on my last trip to NOLA.  mmmm

Anyway, the breakfast sandwich was excellent.  I will definitely have to go back.  I was there later in the day and didn't see any screaming ladies.  The staff was friendly and it seemed like a great neighborhood restaurant.
author: Carol C.

description:
The food here is solid.  It honestly is probably only 3/12 or 4 stars ... but ... they make the most insane biegnets ever (except Cafe de Monde in New Orleans, but come on) - insane enough to bump it all the way up!

Staff is awesome too.  They have this great balance of being friendly but kind of with this harsh attitude that I totally love.  Like most breakfast places, the wait sucks, but you tell me of a great bfast place in the city that doesn't have a wait on the weekends.
author: Montana D.

description:
I've been here a few times.  Its a cute little place.  Depending on what time you go, you'll have a long wait.

I tried each type of pancake: buttermilk, corn meal and buckwheat.  
 - All of them were delicious.

I always order the cowgirl, which comes with pancakes, either bacon or sausage and eggs any style.  I never had the sausage, but the bacon is always cooked the way I like it.  

Minus one star because of the wait.  But it's worth it.
author: Delilah B.

description:
I wish I could have brunch everyday, but I would probably gain 50lbs. lol!!

I went here for brunch with a few friends and we had to wait a bit for a table for five. Easy parking though. Well worth the wait.

Service was pretty good, my coffee cup was kept full, although the first time we did have to ask. Milk on the table also needed a refill. I had the corned beef hash special with biscuits and eggs over easy. We also shared a plate of beignets. Mmmm....the corned beef hash was freshly made with large/small chunks of corned beef, potatoes, red peppers, and onions. The biscuits were freshly baked and were very good too. The beignets were to die for, you must try them if you come here. Share a plate of three with friends or order individually. We actually got a plate of four.

You'll need some beta for the bathroom situation. So there's a restroom sign and the door actually doesn't have a handle. But, there's also another bathroom further back and to the left around the corner. There's no sign to label it because it's probably for the staff, but they don't seem to mind if you use it. Although, they may not actually tell you it's there when they see you waiting in front of the other bathroom.
author: Kenny J.

description:
Probably my favorite laid-back brunch locale in SF.  Their dishes are always fantastic, though there is often a wait.  What you really go there for though are the beniegts.  An order has 3 huge powdered sugar covered pillows of pure heaven - eat 'em while they're warm!

The service is always on top of making sure you have a full cup of coffee.

For all you people saying "its so far away" - if you go on the weekends you can take the brand spanking new T line!  Plus its a free ride on the way back!
author: Shane L.

description:
This is my new favorite diner.  The owner Arienne Landry and the staff, Abigail especially, is great too.  

The only thing I get is the green chili cheese burger with green chili smothered on the fries too.  It's hot and yummy! And they get it from New Mexico, Hatch New Mexico Green Chili is the best, I know this because I am a New Mexican and I love chili.

Also had a dessert, it was a Louisiana Praline cookie thing in ice cream with caramel syrup, it was oh so good.

Eat here it rocks!
author: Mike R.

description:
I don't know how I feel about this place. Sure, it's cute, and the art on the walls is actually interesting, unlike the art on the walls at most LA hipster spots. The waiter was good - not too chirpy, not too sullen - and the service was quick. Prices are also good. As for the food, the bread was fantastic. I had the asparagus sandwich. There was a really tasty spread on it, and lots of yummy veggies, but the asparagus was pretty tough - so much so that I couldn't bite it (which you have to do because they use large, uncut stalks). We didn't have the begniets, but I have it on good authority that they are great. 

The downside is their attitude toward the customers as communicated through notes on their menu and posted signs.  Could these be jokes? Possibly, but they come off as nagging micro-management ("hey kids, don't be a jerk and talk on your cell phone while eating", "here's a tip - throw your trash in the trash can, not on the floor" - I made those up). Like they can't tolerate people very much so they have to create their own version of you. Hey man, it's cool. I generally agree that people are inconsiderate slobs - you won't get any argument from me there. Maybe I just don't like the inference that I might be an inconsiderate slob.
author: Marcelle H.

description:
Good food, good service.. and the beignets were pretty good too. Try the french toast though. That's why I'll come back.
Oh ya, turn off your cell phone.. it's the rule here, as it should be MOST places.
author: John R.

description:
Holy shit, the beignets!  Even after having a big breakfast which left me completely full, I had to order them.  And, although they were to-go, we pretty much scarfed half of it all up by the time we got to our car after leaving the restaurant!  So very yummy!  It comes out hot, fresh, crispy, yet soft and pillowy, not to mention with a large amount of powder sugary goodness!

Aside from the beignets, I had the Greg's Scramble with bacon.  The eggs were scrambled soft, just the way I like it, without me having to ask for it.  We also had an order of their clam chowder.  I've never had clam chowder with a chile in it, but it added a surprisingly nice kick to it.

The service was alright; pretty laid back -- the girls that were working there the day I dined here didn't seem too friendly (they hardly ever smiled), but they did their job and my coffee/water was filled when needed.  Also, I don't know if it had anything to do with sitting by the window/door, but we had to occasionally swat away the flies that kept trying to steal our food, how dare they!

Overall, pretty good place to have breakfast -- but really, their beignets... oh man!
author: Crys L.

description:
i love my neighborhood cafe! i always order off the "specials" menu, and have never been disappointed. i think my ultimate fav was something like a "guinness beef hash" or some nonsense, and that shit killed my hangover and kept me full until dinner. and heeeeeeyyyy- they have mimosas, as well as cypresses (champagne and grapefruit j). 

the joint starts filling up early (i don't know what it is about san franciscans, but ya'll should try sleeping in some!), with a solid line starting to form by 9am.
author: cristina s.

description:
This is a lovely neighborhood restaurant with friendly, accommodating service and delicious, fresh food.  There can be a wait on the weekends but it's made easier by the free coffee outside (get a mug inside).

I always start off with a light-as-air beignet and am a huge fan of their New Mexico green chili to go along with any of their egg dishes.  Also, if the special is corned beef hash, make sure to order!
author: Nhi N.

description:
A good hearty meal always.  The lunch specials always hit the spot.  The fish is never overcooked.

Save room for the beignettes, have them fresh and hot (if you have to choose, I say doggie bag some of the lunch, just so you can have one).  The beignettes finish the lunch off nicely but overall they have a sour note to them.  Its more the novelty effect than the actual quality of the pastry itself.

Service is always friendly and kind.
Decor is hilarious if you spend the time to look at it (ie: boring date or eating alone if you bore yourself...)
author: H C.

description:
Cute place! Wish it was in the Mission, but hey, then it probably would lose some of its appeal! 

I saw their coupon on the back of my Safeway receipt, and decided to check it out. They make their own bread, and it's very hearty! I had the crabcake sandwich and my boyfriend had the catfish fillet with eggs and grits...the main thing that stood out to us, though, me was the super friendly service. Both of the guys manning the place were so nice and down to earth. 

I might come here for another weekday breakfast to give the beignets a try!
author: Shannon R.

description:
What an appropriate name.  Their menu suits me perfectly:  you have the option for grits instead of homefries, they have longanisa, offer beignets, and their mimosas are served in pint glasses!!

The staff are super cool and the parking easy breezy.  The only problem was that its located at the far end of the city from me. If it was in my 'hood, I'll be there all the time buying beignets by the dozen.
author: Ezduzit S.

description:
Uh oh.  I might be a dissenter here, because everyone else wants to give 4+ stars.
But I had lunch here last week and was frankly a bit disappointed by the main course and the reverberant noise level  (the Beignets, did NOT disappoint and were everything the reviewers have promised).

First the noise: I watched servers and the manager YELL at each other to get simple orders done and at least two phone orders failed because the person on the register couldn't hear the speaker.  They have Anechoic foam blocks (the funny little pyramids) on the ceiling----but they need A LOT MORE given the noise level the flat, hard surfaces in this place generate.  Even the staff thinks so--although they might not say it to your face.

I had the Crab Cake Po'Boy sandwich with a side of coleslaw and ice tea.  OK, I have my expectations; the crab cakes should taste mostly of crab, not filling; the roll should be good, but not too thick; the mayo should add something, perhaps by being really fresh or by having something a little spicy in it.  But the Crab cake tasked a bit too much of filling, the roll sort of detracted---and the mayo just didn't do it for me.  The coleslaw was very good (not too creamy); the ice tea smooth and not bitter, the Beignets were reason enough to come here---but the main act, the sandwich, just didn't soar.  And I was saddened.
The Beignets I got to go, however, redeemed 99% of the experience.

I'll go back and give it another shot; maybe the catfish Po'Boy is the way to go.
author: Roger W.

description:
I had a late breakfast here on Friday, Jan. 11th. 

I loved the ambiance. Nice colors. Loved the menu's design.

I had the CowGirl breakfast. They cooked my eggs perfectly. My sausage was to die for, cooked to perfection. The french toast was good but I like cinnamon on mine. 
I was not too crazy about the beignet but it's my first time having it. I just thought it was kind of boring, it needs chocolate. 

Our waitress took a long time to give us a refill on our coffee but after I mentioned it they kept the coffee coming. 
Too bad they don't have chicken fried steak and eggs because that is my all time favorite breakfast dish.
I will try to have lunch here next time. They had a pasta special that sounded and looked delicious.
author: Lorraine B.

description:
As one of my many birthday celebrations this month, my friends took me out to brunch last Sunday here. I was really looking forward to it because I heard the beignets are bangin' and I've read the rave reviews about the place.
